meta.description: Canonical glossary — field definitions for all governed data sheets

fields.definition: This field stores an internal or external account reference number used to uniquely identify the account across systems. It is not sourced from contracts and is primarily used for integrations, reconciliation, or reporting.

This picklist indicates how the account relationship originated (for example, inbound lead source, referral, or specific campaign). It is CRM metadata only and is not extracted from contract language.

This field stores an estimate of the account’s annual revenue when available from onboarding, external data providers, or internal research. It is used for segmentation and prioritization and is not normally stated in contracts.
This is the adress of the entity we're signing. Most contracts will have a version of this, sometimes partial. We'll need to get it, break it into its different field, and complete what's missing.

This field stores the city portion of the account’s billing address. Populate it from the address block in contracts or onboarding materials when available; otherwise it may be completed from client-provided data.

This field stores the country portion of the account’s billing address. Populate it from the address block in contracts or onboarding materials when available; otherwise use client-provided information.
This picklist records the geocoding accuracy level for the billing address (for example, rooftop, postal code, city). It is populated by address/geocoding services and not from contract text.
This field stores the latitude coordinate associated with the billing address, typically derived from geocoding. It is system-generated metadata used for mapping and analytics.
This field stores the longitude coordinate associated with the billing address, typically derived from geocoding. It is system-generated metadata used for mapping and analytics.
This field stores the postal or ZIP code for the account’s billing address. Populate it from the address information in the contract or onboarding forms when available.
This field stores the state or province for the account’s billing address. It can be sourced from contract address blocks, onboarding forms, or client-provided data.
This field stores the street line(s) for the account’s billing address. Populate it from the legal address information in contracts or onboarding materials when available.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who created the account record. It is audit metadata and is never extracted from contracts.
This system field stores the date and time when the account record was created in Salesforce. It is used for auditing and reporting, not contract extraction.

This picklist indicates the primary transactional currency associated with the account record. It supports multi-currency reporting and is set based on internal configuration and business context, not contract language.

This long-text field is used to store free-form internal notes and context about the account (for example, relationship history, key risks, or strategic notes). It is not intended for direct clause extraction.
This field stores the account’s fax number when provided. It is sourced from onboarding or business contact information, not typically from contracts.
This field stores the Salesforce record ID or an equivalent system identifier for the account in text form. It is used for integrations and reporting and is not sourced from contract text.
This picklist classifies the account’s primary industry (for example, Music, Media, Technology). It is a CRM segmentation field and is not typically present in contract language.
This checkbox indicates whether the account is enabled for a customer portal or similar external access. It is a system/operations field and is not taken from contracts.
This field stores the Data.com (Jigsaw) key for the account when synced from that service. It is third-party metadata used for enrichment, not contract-derived.
This field stores the Jigsaw (Data.com) company identifier for the account. It is used for data enrichment and deduplication, not for contract extraction.
This field records the date of the most recent activity logged against the account (for example, task, event, or email). It is CRM interaction metadata, not from the contract.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who last modified the account record. It is used for auditing and is not contract-based.
This system field stores the date and time of the last update to the account record. It is audit metadata only.
This lookup identifies the master account record when this record is part of a merge or hierarchy. It is CRM merge metadata and is not sourced from the contract.
Depending on who's client in the contract, this is either Artist Name or Company Name.

This field stores the approximate number of employees for the account when known. It can come from onboarding forms, client disclosures, or data providers and is used for segmentation, not typically from contracts.
This lookup links the account to an Operating Hours definition, if used for support or service-level tracking. It is operational metadata, not contract data.
This lookup identifies the Salesforce user or queue that currently owns the account. It supports routing and responsibility and is not sourced from contracts.

This picklist describes the ownership structure of the account company (for example, Public, Private, Subsidiary), distinct from contract ownership concepts. It is CRM metadata and typically comes from research or onboarding, not directly from contracts.
Wouldn't be in the contract
This field stores the primary phone number for the account. It is sourced from onboarding, websites, or business cards rather than directly from contract clauses.
This field stores a URL to an image representing the account (for example, logo or artist photo). It is purely presentational/operational and not taken from contracts.
Wouldn't be in the contract
Wouldn't be in the contract
This composite address field stores the shipping address for the account when different from the billing address. It is sourced from onboarding or logistics data, not typically from contracts.
This field stores the city for the account’s shipping address. It is operational address data, not usually extracted from contracts.
This field stores the country for the account’s shipping address. It supports logistics and regional reporting and is not generally taken from contract language.
This picklist records the geocoding accuracy level for the shipping address. It is populated by geocoding services and not from contracts.
This field stores the latitude coordinate of the shipping address, typically set by geocoding. It is system metadata only.
This field stores the longitude coordinate of the shipping address, typically set by geocoding. It is system metadata only.
This field stores the postal or ZIP code for the shipping address. It is populated from client-provided address information, not contract text.
This field stores the state or province for the account’s shipping address. It is used for logistics and regional reporting.
This field stores the street line(s) for the account’s shipping address. It is sourced from client-provided operational data, not contracts.
This field stores the Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) code associated with the account’s industry when available. It is external classification metadata, not contract-based.
This field stores a human-readable description corresponding to the SIC code for the account. It is reference metadata to support reporting and segmentation.
This field stores a site or location descriptor for the account (for example, a specific office or branch name) when multiple locations exist. It is CRM metadata, not contract-derived.
This field stores the stock ticker symbol if the account is a publicly traded company. It is used for external reference and financial context, not contract extraction.
This field stores the Einstein or internal account tier classification (for example, A/B/C) used for prioritization. It is a derived/analytical field, not a contract field.

This field represents the type of client we're signing in a contract. On a high level, it's a company vs an individual. In most contracts, it's going to be Artist, Band, Record Label, or Management Company.
This field stores the main website URL for the account. It is sourced from onboarding or public information and not from contract clauses.
This lookup identifies the current A&R owner assigned to the account. It is internal routing and ownership information, not extracted from contracts.
This field records whether and how the account has accepted applicable terms of service (for example, via online flows). It is onboarding/compliance metadata and not from contract PDFs.
This field stores a prefilled Typeform or onboarding link for the account to complete required information. It is an operational tool URL, not a contract-derived value.
This field stores a primary Apple Music profile or channel URL for the account (for example, an artist or label page). It is generally sourced from onboarding or research, not contracts.
This is the date of birth of the individual being signed. It's required for contracts with individuals. Optional for contracts with companies.
This field represents the professional name of the artist or Band. It's required for all contract where we're signing an individual, or contracts signing a company, for 1 or 2 individuals
This formula or checkbox field indicates whether the billing address is considered complete/valid according to internal rules. It is derived from address components, not contract text.
This formula field stores a formatted account name used by BOFC (Bulk Object Field Creator) or similar tooling. It is for internal configuration and not a contract field.
This lookup links the account to a related cash advance record or configuration when used at the account level. It references financial setup, not a specific contract clause.

This field captures a certification statement or status indicating that the account asserts ownership or control of the content it delivers. It is typically collected during onboarding or via forms, not from deal contracts themselves.

This field stores notes about categories of content that are restricted for CMA (Content Monetization Administration) for this account at a global/client level (for example, types of videos or topics that should not be monetized). It complements contract-level CMA restrictions and is usually collected via CPA/CMA onboarding or policy discussions.
This field stores a CBMG-specific account prefill link used to gather standardized information from the client. It is a workflow URL, not a contract-derived value.
This field stores the profit attributed to this account for the year 2022 according to internal reporting. It is a historical metric, not a contract extraction.
This field represents the business name of the company we's signing. It's required for all contract where we're signing a business regardless if management or record label.
This formula field stores the company name in all caps for use in generated documents and templates. It is derived from `company_name_c` and not extracted separately from contracts.

This formula/checkbox field indicates that the company does not represent artists (for example, a brand or non-artist business). It is derived from `Account_Type_c` and related fields, not directly read from contract text.

This formula/checkbox field indicates that the company represents artists (for example, a management company or label). It is derived from account type and role configuration, not from contract clauses.

This currency field stores the current total of outstanding or committed advances associated with this account across deals, based on roll-ups or calculations. It is a financial summary, not a single contract clause.

This currency field represents the current earnings attributed to this account, typically aggregated from statements or reporting systems. It is used operationally for finance and A&R and is not read from contracts.

This field represents the legal name of the artist or the legal name of individuals that form a Band. It's required for all contract where we're signing an individual, or contracts signing a company, for 1 or 2 individuals
This field stores a prefill link used to collect deal term details from the client or internal teams (for example, Typeform or similar). It is workflow infrastructure, not contract data.
This legacy picklist stores an older division classification for the account. It is retained for backward compatibility and reporting and is not sourced from contracts.
This field stores the URL to the account’s primary Facebook page when available. It is sourced from onboarding or research, not contracts.
This field stores the date on which the account first signed any contract with CMG. It is derived from related Opportunities/agreements and is not taken from a single contract field.
This field stores Google Click Identifier (GCLID) or related tracking parameters associated with the account’s acquisition. It is marketing attribution data, not contract-derived.
Won't be in the contract

This formula/checkbox field indicates whether the account represents an individual rather than a company, derived from `Account_Type_c` and related fields. It is a classification helper, not a contract field.
Won't be in the contract
This field can store a list or reference to prior-year account IDs used for historical mapping or migration. It is data migration/support metadata, not contract-based.
Won't be in the contract
This formula field stores the legal name of the artist/individual in all caps for contract drafting and templates. It is derived from `dba_name_c` or related fields, not extracted independently.

This lookup links the account to a Letter of Direction (LOD) record at the account level when applicable. It connects party identity to standing instructions but is not itself a field extracted from contracts.
Won't be in the contract

This formula field indicates whether the artist/individual associated with the account is a minor under the relevant jurisdiction. It may be derived from `artist_birthday_c` and is used for drafting and compliance, not directly read as a word from contracts.

This long-text field stores internal notes intended to be communicated to the client (for example, in onboarding or support interactions). It is not sourced from contracts and should not be used for legal clause storage.
This checkbox indicates whether the account has completed the required onboarding steps (for example, forms, KYC, payment setup). It is operational status, not contract-derived.
This roll-up summary counts the number of Opportunities (deals) associated with the account. It is a system-generated metric, not a contract field.
This text field can store historical owner information or a log of previous account owners for audit/reference purposes. It is internal metadata only.

This picklist stores the default payment frequency preference for the account (for example, monthly, quarterly) used when setting up statements or payouts. It is typically informed by client onboarding or finance configuration, not by contract language (which is modeled at Opportunity level).

This field stores the default number of days between statement issuance and payment for this account, when managed at the account level. It is a configuration preference rather than a direct contract extraction.

This field stores a default minimum payment threshold for the account (for example, do not pay out until earnings exceed a specific amount). It may mirror or complement contract-level thresholds but is maintained as an account preference.
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
This field stores the record type identifier inherited or mapped from a Lead during conversion. It is migration metadata, not sourced from contracts.
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
This is a list of USA states where a company might be legally formed in. We have an "outside USA" option. In addition, not all contract would have this detail in them.
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
This formula DateTime field is used as a time-based trigger for automations or workflows related to the account. It is not populated from contract text.
This roll-up summary counts the total number of deals (Opportunities) ever associated with the account. It is an analytical metric, not contract data.
This roll-up summary counts the number of term-based deals (for example, where a term field is present) tied to the account. It is used for analysis and is not taken from a specific contract clause.
This roll-up summary counts the total number of closed-won deals associated with the account. It is sales/BD reporting metadata, not a contract field.
This field stores the URL to the account’s Twitter/X profile when available. It is sourced from onboarding or research, not extracted from contracts.
This field is used for contracts with companies. It defines the type of legal entity behind the company. Or the lack of it. It's sadly not available in all contracts.
This lookup links the account to a Typeform Form Mapping configuration defining which form and mappings apply to this account. It is workflow setup, not contract-derived.
This field stores the response identifier from Typeform (or similar) for the most recent or primary onboarding submission related to this account. It is external form metadata.
This formula field stores the 18-character Salesforce ID of the account record as text. It is used for integrations and exports and is not sourced from contracts.
This is the YouTube link of a client. it's usually in CPA contracts.
This field stores a secondary YouTube channel URL for the account when multiple channels exist. It is sourced from onboarding or research, not contracts.
This field stores a third YouTube channel URL for the account when applicable. It is operational/channel-mapping data, not contract-derived.
This field stores the primary YouTube channel name associated with the account. It is collected for CPA/CMA operations and branding and is not generally present in deal contracts.

This lookup links the contact to its parent account (for example, artist, label, management company, or brand). It is the core relationship that tells the system which party this person represents in contracts and operations.
This field stores the full name of the contact’s assistant when provided. It is used for routing communications or scheduling through an intermediary, not as a legal party to contracts.

This field stores the phone number of the contact’s assistant. Use it when the assistant is the primary scheduling or coordination point; it is not a notice address for contracts unless explicitly designated elsewhere.
This field stores the contact’s date of birth when known. It is used for KYC, age verification, and context, but is typically collected via onboarding rather than directly from contract PDFs.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who created the contact record. It is audit metadata only and is not sourced from contract language.
This system field records the date and time when the contact record was created in Salesforce. It supports auditing and reporting, not contract extraction.
This field indicates the currency context associated with the contact record in multi-currency orgs. It is system metadata and does not come from the contract itself.

This field stores the department or functional area the contact belongs to (for example, Legal, A&R, Finance, Marketing). It is typically gathered from onboarding or signatures blocks and is used to understand the contact’s role within their organization.
This long-text field is used for internal notes about the contact, such as relationship context, communication preferences, or risk notes. It should not be used to store full contract clauses.
This checkbox indicates that the contact should not be called by phone for marketing or outreach purposes. It is a compliance/governance flag, not a contract concept.
This would be the email of the contact. It's usually in the signing block or signing log at the end of the contract
This field stores the date and time when an email to the contact last bounced. It is maintained by email infrastructure and used to keep contact info healthy, not by contract extraction.
This field stores the reason code or explanation for the last email bounce event for this contact. It is operational metadata to support list hygiene.
This field stores the business fax number for the contact when available. It is sourced from business cards, onboarding, or signatures, not typically from the body of the contract.
This is the first name of the contact
This checkbox indicates that the contact has opted out of marketing or bulk email communications. It is a compliance flag, not a legal notice preference clause.
This checkbox indicates that the contact has opted out of receiving fax communications for marketing or outreach. It is managed operationally and is not sourced from contract text.
This field stores the contact’s home phone number when provided. It is generally used for personal contacts and should not be used as the default business phone unless explicitly authorized.
This is the Salesforce internal ID for the contact record. It is system-generated and used for integrations and references, not extracted from contracts.
This lookup links the contact to an underlying Individual record used by Salesforce’s Person Accounts/Individuals model. It is CRM infrastructure metadata, not contract data.

This field stores an informal or preferred name for the contact (for example, nickname or short form) when needed for communication, while the `Name` field remains the full legal name for drafting and compliance.
This checkbox indicates whether the last attempted email to this contact bounced. It is set by email systems and used to avoid sending to invalid addresses.
This field stores the Data.com (Jigsaw) key for the contact when synced from that service. It is third-party enrichment metadata and not sourced from contracts.
This field stores the Jigsaw (Data.com) contact identifier used for enrichment and deduplication. It is not contract-derived.
This field stores the date of the most recent logged activity (task, call, event, etc.) associated with the contact. It tracks engagement history, not contract clauses.
This field stores the date/time a Stay-in-Touch request was last sent to the contact. It is Salesforce feature metadata.
This field stores the date/time when the contact last responded to or updated a Stay-in-Touch request. It is CRM metadata.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who last modified the contact record. It supports auditing and change tracking, not contract extraction.
This system field stores the date and time of the last update to the contact record. It is audit metadata.
This is the last name of the contact
This picklist tracks how the contact was originally sourced (for example, referral, web form, campaign). It is CRM attribution metadata and is not sourced from contracts.

This composite field stores the full mailing address for the contact (street, city, state, postal code, country). Populate from the address information available in signatures, onboarding forms, or client-provided data; break into component fields as needed.
This field stores the city portion of the contact’s mailing address. It is part of the contact’s correspondence details, not a contract clause.
This field stores the country portion of the contact’s mailing address. It supports regional routing and compliance and is not itself a contract term.
This picklist records the geocoding accuracy level for the contact’s mailing address (for example, rooftop vs postal code). It is system-populated metadata.
This field stores the latitude coordinate for the contact’s mailing address, derived via geocoding. It is used for mapping and analytics.
This field stores the longitude coordinate for the contact’s mailing address, derived via geocoding. It is used for mapping and analytics.
This field stores the postal or ZIP code for the contact’s mailing address. It is populated from contact-provided address data or signature blocks.
This field stores the state or province associated with the contact’s mailing address. It is used for regional routing and compliance.
This field stores the street line(s) for the contact’s mailing address. It is sourced from signatures, onboarding forms, or direct contact data.
This lookup identifies the master contact record when this record is merged or part of a hierarchy. It is merge metadata created by Salesforce.
This field stores the contact’s legal middle name when provided. It supplements `FirstName` and `LastName` for formal drafting and identification, especially where required for notarization or KYC.
This field stores the contact’s mobile phone number. It is used for direct communication and sometimes for multi-factor authentication, not as a contractual notice address unless explicitly agreed.
This would be the full legal name of the contact.

This composite field stores an alternate address for the contact (for example, secondary office or home address). It is operational context, not normally a legal notice address unless specifically designated.
This field stores the city portion of the contact’s alternate address.
This field stores the country portion of the contact’s alternate address.
This picklist records the geocoding accuracy level for the alternate address. It is system metadata.
This field stores the latitude coordinate for the contact’s alternate address, derived via geocoding.
This field stores the longitude coordinate for the contact’s alternate address, derived via geocoding.
This field stores an alternate phone number for the contact, such as a secondary office or home line.
This field stores the postal or ZIP code of the contact’s alternate address.
This field stores the state or province of the contact’s alternate address.
This field stores the street line(s) of the contact’s alternate address.
This lookup identifies the Salesforce user or queue that owns the contact record. It is used for routing and responsibility and is not extracted from contracts.
This field stores the primary business phone number for the contact. It is typically taken from business cards, email signatures, or onboarding, not the contract body.
This field stores a URL to an image representing the contact (for example, profile photo). It is presentational metadata only.

This field indicates the type of the schedule. And as a result, different fields would be required in the schedule catalog object. Which is a joint table between schedule and catalog. This is an enumerated identifier that tags each Schedule with its specific deal subtype (e.g., “Ownership,” “Termination,”). This single value drives all conditional logic: it tells the system which extra fields, page layouts, and validation rules to load in the Schedule–Catalog junction, ensuring that only data relevant to that deal subtype can be displayed, entered, or processed. This field cannot be empty.
This lookup links the contact to another contact they report to (for example, manager or supervisor). It models org hierarchy and is used for relationship context, not contract terms.
This picklist stores the contact’s salutation (for example, Mr., Ms., Dr.) for use in correspondence and formal addressing. It is usually collected via onboarding or contact entry.
This field stores any legal suffix associated with the contact’s name (for example, Jr., Sr., III, Esq.). It is important for precise legal naming in drafting.
This field stores the contact’s job title or role within their organization (for example, CEO, Head of A&R, General Counsel). It is often taken from the contract signature block or email signature.

This formula field concatenates the various address components into a single contact address string for display or export. It is derived from mailing or other address fields and is not directly extracted from contracts.
This field stores the normalized city for the contact’s primary address in a CMG-specific format, typically mirroring `MailingCity` for downstream templates or data flows.
This field stores the normalized country value for the contact’s primary address, used in generated documents, exports, or integrations.
This field stores a normalized or alternate email for the contact, typically used for workflows or external integrations when a single canonical email value is needed.
This field mirrors or normalizes the contact’s first name for CMG-specific processes or document templates. It should stay consistent with the core `FirstName` field.
This formula field stores the Salesforce Contact ID as text for use in exports, mappings, or downstream apps that require a text identifier instead of the native ID type.
This field mirrors or normalizes the contact’s last name for CMG-specific processes or document templates. It should stay consistent with the core `LastName` field.
This field mirrors or normalizes the contact’s middle name for use in templates or integrations where a separate middle-name field is required.
This field stores a normalized or alternate phone number for the contact, often used for document merge fields or integrations instead of the native `Phone` field.
This field stores the normalized state or province value for the contact’s primary address, aligned to CMG’s internal formatting.
This field stores the normalized street line(s) for the contact’s primary address for use in document templates and exports.
This field stores an additional address line for the contact (for example, apartment, suite, or building information) in CMG’s normalized format.
This field stores the normalized postal or ZIP code for the contact’s primary address used in document templates and exports.
This formula field stores a contact identifier (often the Salesforce ID or a shortened variant) used in specific integrations or reports that require a numeric-looking ID string.
This legacy picklist stores an older division classification associated with the contact. It is retained for backward compatibility and internal reporting.

This is the name of the label that the contract is with. It's usually at the top of the contract. Either in the title of the first paragraph. This is not the Artist or a thrid party name. If there is no specified Label, return "None Specified"
This field stores the Legal Entity ID associated with the contact when they are tied to a specific legal entity record in Finance or compliance systems. It is integration metadata, not contract text.
This field captures the high-level purpose or reason this contact exists in CMG’s CRM (for example, signatory, legal contact, business contact, A&R liaison). It is an internal classification field.
This field stores the record type identifier inherited or mapped from a Lead when the contact is created via lead conversion. It is migration/attribution metadata.

This multiselect picklist describes the roles the contact plays in CMG’s ecosystem (for example, Artist, Manager, Lawyer, Label Rep, Publisher). It is used to route communications and understand how this person interacts with deals and accounts.

This field stores an alternate email address for the contact (for example, personal vs work email). It can be used as a backup communication channel but is not usually the formal notice address unless specified.
This field stores a secondary phone number for the contact, such as a second mobile or office line.

This formula field returns the current date and is used in time-based formulas or automation involving the contact (for example, calculating age or time since last activity). It is system logic, not contract data.

This lookup links the contact to a Typeform form mapping configuration, defining which external form and field mappings apply when gathering data from this contact. It is workflow configuration metadata.
This is the number of days where the artist and label promise not to distribute any new music in. It's an optional section in distribution and exclusive licensing contracts.

This is the purcentage of an asset (or assets) that the label acquired as part of a CoPub or Asset Purchase agreement. It's usually in the first part of a contract in the middle of a paragraph. If it is 0, keep this field empty

This field indicates the controlled composition percentage that applies to the writer/composer share when the agreement contains a controlled composition clause. Populate this field only when the contract explicitly defines a controlled composition percentage or limit for compositions covered by the deal; if no controlled composition provision appears, leave this field blank.
This is an optional way on how to uncross a new contract with an existing contract or track. To be honest, we've only seen it once so far.

This is an optional percentage that speficy the Administration fee that the label is charging to service a Publishing Administration contract or a Co-Publishing contract. It's usually in the middle of the contract, in a paragraph after the splits section.
A paragraph that explains how and when the advance should be paid along with any clause if linked
fields.example_output: One Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($1,500) (the “Fee”), Fifty Percent (50%) of which shall be deemed a recording cost and Fifty Percent (50%) of which shall be deemed an advance fully recoupable against Producer’s royalty.

fields.definition: This field stores the exact or near‑exact advance wording in sentence/paragraph form (for example, how the advance is described, recouped, or tied to deliverables). Use it when the drafting language around the advance needs to be preserved verbatim or closely paraphrased in addition to structured financial fields.

This field stores the effective date of the affiliation agreement referenced in the contract (for example, a PRO or publisher affiliation agreement) when that date is expressly stated. If no specific affiliation agreement date is provided in the materials, leave this field blank.
This is a dropdown that indicates if the contracts includes anything uncrossed (not cross collaterized). Default is NO. If yes, it depends on what is uncrossed.
options: Asset: Might be a portion of Assets

fields.definition: This field captures contractual limitations on the company’s right to exploit works, catalog, or services (for example, approval works lists, media restrictions, or platform carve‑outs). Summarize the operative limitation language so that downstream users understand where company rights are narrowed or subject to pre‑approval.

This is a specific page around the end of the contract. It's usually added if the contract is signed with a Label for a specific client. The field in Salesforce is a checkbox. It's checked if the Inducement Paragraph/page are in the contract, unchecked if not.
This is a manually entered field in SF that indicates the location of the audio file that we bought as part of the related record.
This is a checkbox that indicates if the contracts includes back catalog (sometimes it's called "Existing Masters".

This represents the percentage (commision) the label charges as a fee to re-distribute the back catalog (or existing masters) as a fee on top of the revenue sharing split. it's usually in the middle of the contract around the Revenue sharing paragraph and points.

This is the percentage of revenue sharing for existing masters (back catalog) mentioned in the contract. It's not frequent to have this value on its own. It indicates the client share from the revenue.
This dropdown indicates if we're taking over all of the back catalog of the client, or a portion of it. If back catalog is not mentioned in the contract, the value would be NULL
This is used ONLY when it's a distribution contract with Content monetization as an add-on, AND CMA has it's own term that is different than the distribution one.
This is used ONLY when it's a distribution contract with Content monetization as an add-on, AND CMA has it's own renewal term that is different than the distribution one.

This field captures any content categories that are restricted or excluded from Content Monetization Administration (CMA) under the agreement (for example, specific channels, topics, or types of content that cannot be monetized or require prior approval). Populate only when the CMA section or related restrictions explicitly limit what the company may monetize.
This field indicates the split of the Content Monetization revenue. It indicates the client share from the revenue.
This is used ONLY when it's a distribution contract with Content monetization as an add-on, AND CMA has it's own termination notice that is different than the distribution one.
This is a required field when the contract includes CMA. It defines what type of content monetization is included in the contract.

A collection period is the time during which the label is allowed to collect revenue from the property or asset after the end of the exploitation period. Sometimes it's referred to as "Sell Off Period"

This field stores the email address designated for contract execution, notices, or deal correspondence for the opportunity. Populate from signature blocks, notice provisions, or deal paperwork where a specific contract contact email is identified.

This field stores the full name of the primary contract contact for the opportunity (for example, the person signing or receiving notices). Populate from the signature block, notice section, or other explicit identification of the authorized representative.

This is an internal workflow field indicating whether the cash advance terms for this opportunity have been approved under company policy. It is not expected to be populated from contract text and is used to control internal approval and processing.

This internal operational field records the number of days allocated or actually taken for drafting the contract. It is used for workflow and performance tracking and is not sourced from any clause in the agreement.

This field stores the operational contract end date for the opportunity, derived either from an explicit end date in the agreement or from the term structure (initial term, renewals, and any post‑term exploitation or collection periods). Populate when the end date can be determined from the term language; otherwise leave blank for manual determination.

This field stores standardized or semi‑standardized drafting language related to option album commitments (for example, how an option album is defined and triggered). Use it when an option clause requires specific album‑related wording that should be carried into generated documents or tracked for reference.

This internal workflow field indicates whether any cash components tied to contract options (such as option advances or fees) have been approved. It is not populated from the contract text and is used only for internal governance of option economics.

This internal workflow field indicates whether any marketing‑related spend tied to contract options (for example, marketing advances or budgets) has been approved. It is not extracted from the agreement and is used to gate internal marketing commitments when options are exercised.

This field stores the period associated with contract options (for example, the length of time granted for an option term or exercise window) when the agreement defines a specific option period separate from the main term. Populate based on the option clause; if no option exists, leave this field blank.
This fields indicates the SUB TYPE of row #39. It's dependant on what's entered there.
This field indicates the type of the contract we have. It's DEDUCTED from the contract content.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) that is in favor of the client for Cover Records. It's usually available in Publishing Contracts or CoPub. Or distro/licensing contracts that include publishing rights. Most of the times, it's highlighted separately. But sometimes, especially in licensing contracts with publishing rights, it's deducted as part of the "Net Profits" split.
This is used ONLY when it's a distribution contract with Channel Partnership as an add-on, AND CPA has it's own term that is different than the distribution one.
This is used ONLY when it's a distribution contract with Channel Partnership as an add-on, AND CPA has it's own renewal term that is different than the distribution one.
This field indicates the split of the Channel Partnership revenue. It indicates the client share from the revenue. We usually have multiple splits in that section. We only track the first one.
This is used ONLY when it's a distribution contract with Channel Partnership as an add-on, AND CPA has it's own termination notice that is different than the distribution one.

This required field classifies the Channel Partnership Administration (CPA) service types included in the contract (for example, specific platforms or channel programs) when CPA is in scope. Populate from the CPA section of the agreement; if the deal does not include CPA, this field should remain blank even if marked required in the data model.

This field records the client’s current distributor(s) at the time of contracting when that information is disclosed (for example, in recitals, background sections, or onboarding materials). Use it for context and migration planning; leave blank when no prior distributor is identified.
This is the most recent date when the contract was signed by either parties. It's usually next to the signatures, or at the end of the document in the signing log.

This field is a concise internal narrative summary of the key commercial terms, structure, and unusual points of the deal. It is not a contract clause extraction; it is used to help reviewers and downstream teams quickly understand the shape of the opportunity.

This is a percentage available in distribution and profit participation contracts. It represents the fee charged for the services of Distribution. It's taken off the top BEFORE the distribution split or profit sharing percentages
This is the name of the label that the contract is with. It's usually at the top of the contract. Either in the title of the first paragraph.
fields.return_format: Format will be complicated here. As long as it's the same in the export. Or if it's different, break into multiple CSVs/Sheets

fields.definition: This is a percentage available in distribution and profit participation contracts. It represents the division of revenue of the label share of an agreement (the other share is called artist share) between the label and another entity. It's usually available in contracts between a company (CMG or one of its subsidiaries) and a company (record label, management company, etc).

This is the date when the contract becomes effective. It's usually on top of the first page in most contracts. If an effective date is not clearly stated, the value gets derived from the most recent signing date.

This field stores the primary email address to be used when sending or routing the contract itself (for example, for e‑signature or PDF delivery). Populate from signing instructions, notice provisions, or deal communications where a specific execution email is identified.

This field is applicable when "Territories" (See below) is set to "World Excluding Multiples". That value is used as OTHER when the other options don't apply. However, "Excluded Territories" is a text area that should list all the territories exlcuded from the contract when the other options don't apply.
This field's value depends on the commitment from the client. If they're committing to EXCLUSIVELY deliver to us during the term, that's TIME. Otherwise, it's MASTERS

This is part of a distribution or licensing contract. It represents the total number of existing tracks, or assets (back catalog) brought to the label as part of the contract. The full list (or Schedule) is usually availabe around the end after the signature block in a table or list format as a "Schedule"

An exploitation period is the time during which the label is still allowed to use the property or asset for its intended purpose. It usually starts after the initial term, and before the collection period.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) that is in favor of the client for the distribution of front catalog music, or new masters. It's usually available in Distribution Contracts, or licensing contracts. Most of the times, it's highlighted separately as "Digital Phono Record Delivery (i.e., electronic downloads)". But sometimes, especially in licensing contracts, it's deducted as part of the "Net Profits" split.

This is a money amount usually available in purchase agreements or label ventures. It represents the amount of money we're comitting to give away, but we're holding off on doing so until the client does something.

This required internal status field indicates whether the opportunity is currently in an active internal approval workflow. It is maintained by process logic or users and is not sourced from the contract document.

This required field indicates whether Content Monetization Administration (CMA) is included in the scope of the agreement. Set this to reflect the presence or absence of CMA rights in the contract; use CMA‑specific term, split, and restriction fields when CMA is included.

This required field indicates whether the contract grants the company a collection right or post‑term collection period (for example, the ability to continue collecting revenues after the exploitation term ends). Set this based on explicit collection or sell‑off language in the agreement.
This is a checkbox field that indicates if the contract includes CPA (Channel Partnership) or not.

This field indicates whether the agreement includes a defined publishing royalty share or participation structure in favor of the client (for example, writer or publisher shares of publishing income). Populate when publishing royalty sharing is explicitly in scope, and use in combination with Publishing‑related split fields.

This field indicates the initial term of the contract.
It should be available in every single contract regardless of the type or format.
This field was created for M&A when we initially onboarded them to Sf in 2023. They had this as a column.
This field was created for M&A when we initially onboarded them to Sf in 2023. They had this as a column.

Available only for Contract Type = Licensing Agreement.

This field will indicate if the licensing is exclusive to us, or non exclusive.

This required system field stores the calculated total number of masters associated with the opportunity, derived from committed deliverables, schedules, and any options (for example, base masters plus option masters). It is used for downstream logic and reporting rather than being extracted directly from a single contract clause.

This field indicates if CMG has the rights of first refusal during the term of the agreement or not. We only need to check if there's a paragraph for that in the agreement and return TRUE. Otherwise, return FALSE.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) that is in favor of the client for Mechanical licensing revenue. It's usually available in Publishing Contracts or CoPub. Or distro/licensing contracts that include publishing rights. Most of the times, it's highlighted separately. But sometimes, especially in licensing contracts with publishing rights, it's deducted as part of the "Net Profits" split.

This field indicates if the contract includes a merchandising paragraph. And if it does, are the rights are exclusive to CMG or non-exclusive?
this is usually available in distribution contracts as well as recording and licensing agreements.
This field indicates the split of the merchandizing revenue. It indicates the client share from the revenue.
This fields indicates the status of neighboring rights income in the contracts when it comes to the label share. It is required with 3 different options.

This is mainly used in Licensing agreements. It represents the number of social media posts the client is commited to do to promote the catalog mentioned in the contact. It's usually explicitely defined in the middle of the contracts

This is applicable for Publishing Administration and CoPublishing contracts. It represents the STATE where the contract was notirized by the client. It can be set to NULL if the contract was never notarized.
This indicates the total number of masters committed in a contract. It's usualy a total of tracks available in schedules for distribution and licensing contracts.
This field represents the number of "options" in a contract. The standard is 1 or 2 options.
This is a weird field. It's a number that represents, our of the "Number of New Masters", how many will be distributed as singles?

This required field stores the IPI number of the publisher captured in the OP publisher block for the opportunity. Populate from the deal paperwork, publishing schedules, or registration materials; if it is missing in the source, the record should be flagged for follow‑up because this identifier is needed for publishing administration.

This required field stores the legal name of the publisher associated with the OP publisher block for the opportunity. Use the exact publishing entity name as stated in the agreement or supporting publishing documentation.

This required field stores the performing rights organization (PRO) affiliation for the OP publisher associated with the opportunity (for example, ASCAP, BMI, PRS). Populate from the contract or publishing metadata where the publisher’s PRO is identified.
When a contract includes an option, the option is usually tied to new delivrable by the client. This number represents the total number of masters included in the available options
use this for when there is a additional album in the option ,EP, etc like for regular distro!

This required field captures release‑specific conditions tied to option commitments (for example, which release or project triggers an option, release timing requirements, or sequencing rules). Summarize the operative release conditions from the option clause so downstream teams understand how and when the option content must be released.

This field represents the existance, or lack, of in a distribution or Licensing Contract. It's very rare to find an option in publishing contracts. The option can be a new commitment from the client, or just a buyout.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) that is in favor of the client for OTHER revenue. It's usually available in Publishing Contracts or CoPub. Or distro/licensing contracts that include publishing rights. Most of the times, it's highlighted separately. But sometimes, especially in licensing contracts with publishing rights, it's deducted as part of the "Net Profits" split.

This is a dropdown that indicates if the label is commiting to paying collaborators or not. It's usually a paragraph around the revenue sharing and splits section. In the case of YES, we have 3 versions.
This field represents the frequency in which the label is comitting to pay the client in the contract. It's usually in the Accounting section of a contract, explicitly defined.
This is a number field that represents HOW many days the label has to pay after the end of the cycle. It's explicitly mentioned in most contracts, but some just don't have it.

This field stores a structured or semi‑structured description of the payment schedule for the opportunity (for example, milestones, due dates, or phased payments) when the schedule cannot be fully captured as separate financial records alone. Use it to give an at‑a‑glance view of timing and ordering of payments derived from the payment terms.
This field indicates the minimum amount of money the client should have in his balance, to be paid every payment cycle. It should be in every contract, but it isn't in a decent amount.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) that is in favor of the client for Performance Rights revenue. It's usually available in Publishing Contracts or CoPub. Or distro/licensing contracts that include publishing rights. Most of the times, it's highlighted separately. But sometimes, especially in licensing contracts with publishing rights, it's deducted as part of the "Net Profits" split.
This is the split (or revenue sharing) percentage in favor of the client when a distribution or licensing contract includes a pitching rights and procurement clause. It's not always there.
When a distribution or licensing contract includes a pitching procurement clause, the rights are either Exclusive, or not. This field defines that exclusivity

This is applicable to every contract that includes publishing rights (pub admin or copub). Those rights might be on their own, or part of a distribution or licending contract. Every publishing client, or writer, should be registered with a PRO.
This field is used in contract drafting usually to formulate the sentences with the correct gender. In exctraction, it will need to be deducted from reading the contract.

This field stores the publisher’s residence or principal address when required for publishing administration, notices, or tax/compliance purposes. Populate when the publisher’s address is clearly stated in the contract or related onboarding documents; otherwise leave blank.
This is required in distribution and licensing contracts. It indicates if the contract has any publishing in it, and what type.

This field indicates whether the agreement contains recording‑specific exclusivity (for example, exclusive recording commitments, non‑exclusive recording services, or no recording obligations). Populate based on any recording exclusivity clause when the deal includes a recording component; leave blank when recording commitments are out of scope.
This field represents the number of days in which the label is committing to release an album once all sides agree to it. It's mainly for distribution and licensing contracts
This split exists ONLY in Distribution remix agreements. IT represent the split between the remixer and the artist, on the client side, for a remix.

This field exists in all contract type where we have a renewal. When exlcusivity = Masters, it renews the initial term. When exclusivity=Time, it often renews the exploitation period. 

Renewal means “how long does the term extend automatically after the end of the term?“

This field is available for Pub Admin, CoPub and sync representation contracts. It's also sometimes included in Licensing contracts. It defines any restrictions we might have on high level. None, Sync Licensing, Sample Licensing or both. We have other fields with options that define the exact restrictions for each category.

Retention period is usually the equivalent for Exploitation Period, but for Publishing side of the business. It's an essential part of a publishing admin, coPub or a Distro or Licensing agreement with a publishing component in it. It's usually clearler stated either in the terms section, or in the licensing section.
When a contract has sample licensing restrictions, this field is required to define them.
fields.example_output: Needs Writer Approval, Limits on Fees

fields.definition: This is a merge field with the schedule list (Separate table)

This field categorizes the type or role of any attached schedules referenced by the opportunity (for example, front catalog schedule, back catalog schedule, or acquisition schedule). It is used to organize and interpret linked Schedule and Schedule Catalog records and is not usually stated verbatim in the contract.
This field is exclusively used in termination documents. It define if it's a termination amendment (client needs to sign) or a termination report (just an FYI)

This field indicates whether synchronization uses require prior approval under the agreement (for example, writer, artist, or label approval for certain sync placements). Populate when the sync or restriction clauses explicitly require approval before licensing; otherwise leave blank.
When a contract has sync licensing restrictions, this field is required to define them.
options: Restrictions on Controversial Figures and Entities

fields.definition: This is available for every single contract where we have synchronization licensing rights. It defines if those rights are exclusive or non exclusive.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) percentage in favor of the client when a contract includes a synchronization licensing rights and. It's there for the vast majority of the contracts. Usually explicitely listed. But in some licensing contracts, it needs to be deduced from the "Net Profits" split.

This field stores a normalized, system‑facing summary of the contract term wording (for example, combining initial term, renewal mechanics, and post‑term elements into one human‑readable description). Use it for drafting, exports, or reporting; it should stay consistent with the structured term fields such as Initial_Term_Length__c, Renewal_Term_Length__c, Recoup_Term__c, Exploitation_Period__c, and Collection_Period__c.

This is one of the most important fields, and it's required in all of them. It defines WHEN we start counting the initial term of an agreement. If the contract doens't have a renewal term, it's usually X Number of years or post recoup only. If the contract has renewal, it's any of the 3. It's deduced from HOW the term is written.
options: Later of X amount of years AND post recoup

fields.definition: This is the date when a contract was terminated. It's not available in the contract itself, but in the paperwork for its termination.
This is the date when the client notified us that they'd like to terminate a contract.  It's not available in the contract itself, but in the paperwork for its termination.

This is the period before the end of the term (initial or renewal)  usually defined in the terms where the client can give us notice that they're like to terminate. It's basically a minimum notice period for terminating a contract.

This field is exclusively used in termination documents. It define if it's we're terminating contracts by Effective Date (1 offboarding date per contract) or by catalog release date (multiple offboard dates per contract). It' tricky to find it in older termination documents. Usually deduced from the termination language.

This is a dropdown field that explains where the contract is applicable. It's usually referenced as "Territory" or "Territories" in the contract, or implied in a section in the first half. However, it won't be spelled exactly as the options in Salesforce. We'll need some sort of mapping.
This is usually in Purchase Agreements. It defines the type of share we're buying. Is it the label share (or revenue) or the client side (Artist)?
This is a checkbox that defines if the contract (usually distribution or Licensing) includes a clause for holding back releases or not.
This is a multiselect field that defines the changes in an amendment. They're deduced from the contract content that defines what changed in this paperwork, compared ot the one(s) it's referencing.
This field defines if the termination document is terminating a full contract(s), parts of a contract.

This field indicates whether the writer associated with the publishing component also has an active recording career that is relevant to the deal. Populate from recitals, bios, or context in the contract when explicitly stated or clearly implied; otherwise leave blank.

This field stores the writer’s IPI number for publishing identification and royalty processing. Populate from the agreement, schedules, or external registration data when available; if not provided, leave blank and flag if required by the workflow.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) that is in favor of the client for Writer Print revenue. It's usually available in Publishing Contracts or CoPub. Or distro/licensing contracts that include publishing rights. Most of the times, it's not highlighted separately. And sometimes, especially in licensing contracts with publishing rights, it's deducted as part of the "Net Profits" split.
This is the link for the YouTube channel that is included in the contract. It's usually available when the contract includes CPA (Channel Partnership)
This field indicates whether the contract includes physical distribution (CDs, DVDs, Vinyls, etc). It's a required field.

This field indicates the split for physical distribution between the client and the label.
The field is required if the “Physical Distribution?“ is set to YES.
This field is available for any contract combination that includes distribution.

This field indicates the split for physical distribution between the client and the label when the split outside the USA is different that inside USA.

The field is displaued if the “Physical Distribution?“ is set to YES.

This field is available for any contract combination that includes distribution.

A selloff period A sell‑off period is a defined period after termination or expiration of a distribution agreement during which the distributor may continue selling existing stock (e.g., manufactured CDs/vinyl). No new units can be manufactured unless expressly permitted. the purpose is to allow an orderly wind‑down and avoid waste or financial loss.
When a track is part of an album, this would be the album name.
Sometimes, the contract defines the album type: EP, Single, Compilation, etc.
This is the artist name(s) on the track or asset. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the ISRC of a track. This field is meant to catch that.
In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the ISWC of a publishing asset (work). This field is meant to catch that.
In some cases, the contract includes a schedule with actual release dates for each track or asset. This field is meant to catch that.
When a catalog item mentioned in a contract is a remix of another song, this field is meant to capture the artist name of the remixer. The individual who we're signing to remix a track.

A contract can reference different types of catalog. This field is meant to identify if we're talking about a track, album, general asset, sound recording or a compositon (publishing work). It can also be a combination of multiple catalogs with different types in a single contract.
In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the UPC of a track. This field is meant to catch that.

For publishing assets, we usually talk about a Writer and not an artist. In some cases, the contract includes both. The writer name is usually the legal name of a client. Mentioned in the schedule part of a contract.

This field stores the Apple Music URL for the catalog item when available. It is not sourced from contract language and is primarily used for operational linking and QA between Salesforce catalog records and Apple Music.
This checkbox indicates whether an A&R resource has been assigned to this catalog item. It is an internal operational field and is not extracted from contract text.

This multi-select picklist classifies whether the catalog item carries Publishing rights, Master rights, or both. Use it to flag which right-streams are in scope for this asset in downstream rights and financial workflows.

This field stores an external or system asset identifier used by distribution or third-party systems for this catalog item. It is used for reconciliation and integration, not for direct contract extraction.

This field holds an external ID for the catalog item (for example, an ID from a legacy system or ingestion pipeline). It is used as a stable join key across systems and is not sourced from contract language.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who created the catalog record. It is audit metadata only and not sourced from contracts.
This picklist indicates the currency context associated with this catalog record, primarily for any financial or pricing interactions. It is system metadata, not a direct contract clause.

This is the name of the label that the contract is with. It's usually at the top of the contract. Either in the title of the first paragraph. This is not the Artist or a thrid party name. If there is no specified Label, return "None Specified"

This picklist identifies the label/imprint under which this catalog item is released or managed within CMG’s internal label structure. It is an internal classification field and is not necessarily spelled out in the contract schedules.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who last modified the catalog record. It is used for audit and change tracking, not contract extraction.

This lookup links the catalog item to a Letter of Direction (LOD) or similar instruction record when such a document governs payment routing or royalty redirection for this asset. Populate it when an LOD explicitly applies to this catalog item.

This lookup links the catalog item to an Opportunity (contract) when that contract is the primary governing deal for this asset. It is used to connect catalog items directly to the contract spine for certain workflows; most ownership and rights semantics still live in Schedule and Schedule Catalog.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user or queue that owns the catalog record. It is used for routing, responsibility, and workflow assignment, not sourced from contracts.

This formula field stores the 18-character Salesforce ID for the catalog record in text form. It is used for integrations, exports, or referencing the record externally and is not a contract-derived value.
This field stores the Spotify URL for the catalog item when available. It is an operational link to the live asset on Spotify and is not derived from contract language.
This field represents the amount. It can be the total mentioned in the agreement, or a portion of it if the agreement total is broken into multiple payments.
This is a prepaid, typically recoupable payment made to a party (e.g., an artist or producer) against future earnings or royalties.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who created the financial record. It is audit metadata only and is not sourced from contract language.
This field indicates the currency of the selected financial commitment
This is a number field that defines the total number of days CMG has to pay the payment starting the day it’s triggered.

This field stores the date by which the payment tied to this financial record is due, based on the triggering event and the payment timing logic in the agreement. It is typically calculated from the event completion date plus `Days_to_Payment__c` rather than extracted as an explicit date from the contract.

This picklist indicates whether the triggering event for this financial commitment has occurred (for example, delivery, execution, or threshold being met). Set to "Yes" once the relevant event has happened; otherwise leave as "No".

This field stores the actual date on which the contractual event that triggers this payment occurred (for example, the delivery date of a project or the date of contract execution). It is used together with `Days_to_Payment__c` to determine the payment due date.
This is a dropdown field that indicates the trigger for the financial record. It's usually defined right next to the amount
This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who last modified the financial record. It is used for auditing and change tracking, not contract extraction.
This field is required when the Type is set to Budget. It allows users to specify whether the budget value represents a minimum or maximum amount.
This field is meant for any additional notes around the financial record.
This field links the financial record to its opportunity (Contract)

This formula field derives a human-readable payable status or label based on other attributes of the financial record (for example, trigger status, due date, and payment date). It is calculated by the system and not populated directly from contract language.

In some cases, the contract defines who's getting payed for a fee or an advance. In those cases, this field would link to a CONTACT who's the payee defined in the contract. It will need the same fields defined for contacts.

This field records the date on which the payment associated with this financial record was actually made. It is populated operationally by Finance once payment is processed, not from the contract itself.

This field indicates the type of the schedule. And as a result, different fields would be required in the schedule catalog object. Which is a joint table between schedule and catalog. This is an enumerated identifier that tags each Schedule with its specific deal subtype (e.g., “Ownership,” “Termination,”). This single value drives all conditional logic: it tells the system which extra fields, page layouts, and validation rules to load in the Schedule–Catalog junction, ensuring that only data relevant to that deal subtype can be displayed, entered, or processed. This field cannot be empty.
This field captures the recoup percentage needed for a client in order to trigger a payment. It's required when the Type is set to Recoup Threshold.
This picklist tracks the current payment status of the financial record (for example, "Not Paid" or "Paid"). It is updated as part of payment operations and does not come from contract text.

This field captures the streaming threshold value required for financial calculations when the Type is set to Streaming Threshold.

In some contracts, a payment is triggered when a client reaches a certain number of streams (this field) in a certain number of days (row 23)

This field is heavily related to row 24 (Type). It defines on a high level the SUBTYPE of the financial commitment. In combination with row 24, we would know as an example, if it's a marketing advance or marketing budget.

This field specifies the number of days associated with the threshold for payment calculations.

In some contracts, a payment is triggered when a client reaches a certain number of streams (row 21) in a certain number of days (this field)

This field is heavily related to row 22 (SubType). It defines on a high level the TYPE of the financial commitment. In combination with row 22, we would know as an example, if it's a marketing advance or marketing budget.

This field indicates HOW the marketing budget can be spent. Does it need client approval? Client can spend it on their own? mutual approval? or label can spend it on their own? It's not required unless the Type and SubType combination = Marketing Budget

This field indicates if the financial record (budget, advance, fee, etc) is recoupable or not. If the contract mentions that it's recoupable, value is YES. If it mentions that it's not recoupable, value is NO, otherwise, value is N/A
When a track is part of an album, this would be the album name.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who created the Schedule record. It is audit metadata only and is not sourced from contract language.

This picklist indicates the currency context for monetary values associated with this Schedule, aligning it with the governing Opportunity and any related financials. It is system metadata rather than a direct contract extraction.

This formula field surfaces the relevant label/division context for the Schedule (for example, from the related Opportunity or Account). It is used for reporting and routing and is not extracted directly from contract text.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who last modified the Schedule record. It is used for audit and change tracking, not contract extraction.

This master-detail relationship links the Schedule to its governing Opportunity (contract). It anchors the Schedule bundle to the contract spine so attached catalog can be interpreted and reported under the correct deal.
This field indicates the type of the schedule. And as a result, different fields would be required in the schedule catalog object. Which is a joint table between schedule and catalog.
In some cases, the contract includes a schedule with actual release dates for each track or asset. This field is meant to catch that.

This field stores the count of Schedule Catalog records attached to this Schedule. It is used for governance and reporting on how many catalog items are bundled under this schedule, and is not sourced from a specific contract clause.
This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.

This field represents the percentage of the seller’s interest in the assets on this Schedule that is being acquired by the purchaser. Use it on acquisition/ownership-style schedules where the agreement specifies that only a portion (not necessarily 100%) of the seller’s interest is transferred.

This is the percentage of an asset (or assets) that the label acquired as part of a CoPub or Asset Purchase agreement. It's usually in the first part of a contract in the middle of a paragraph. If this is 0, Keep this field empty.

This field stores the actual date on which the rights for this specific catalog asset were terminated under a termination schedule or related paperwork. It is populated from termination documents or offboarding actions, not from the original deal contract.
When a track is part of an album, this would be the album name.
Sometimes, the contract defines the album type: EP, Single, Compilation, etc.
This is the artist name(s) on the track or asset. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
Writer name
This formula field surfaces the name of the asset owner contact linked via `Asset_Owner__c`. It is used for quick identification and reporting and is not extracted directly from contract language.

This formula field reflects the governed asset type for the attached Catalog record (for example, Master vs Publishing). It is derived from Catalog and used to understand which side of the business (recording vs publishing) each Schedule Catalog row represents.

This master-detail relationship links the Schedule Catalog row to its underlying Catalog item. It ensures each ownership/rights line item is anchored to a governed catalog asset for reporting, offboarding, and rights management.
Track name
This is the % of a composition owned by the human involved in the track/catalog. The human is represented as Asset Owner. It's a contact in Salesforce.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who created the Schedule Catalog record. It is audit metadata only and is not sourced from contract language.

This picklist indicates the currency context for any monetary values or financial interactions tied to this Schedule Catalog row, aligned with the parent Opportunity and Schedule. It is system metadata, not a direct clause extraction.
In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the ISRC of a track. This field is meant to catch that.
In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the ISWC of a publishing asset (work). This field is meant to catch that.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who last modified the Schedule Catalog record. It is used for audit and change tracking, not contract extraction.

This lookup links the Schedule Catalog row to a Letter of Direction (LOD) or similar instruction record, when such a document governs payment routing or royalty redirection for this asset. Populate it when an LOD explicitly applies to the catalog item represented by this row.
This is the % of a sound recording (or Track) owned by the human involved in the track/catalog. The human is represented as Asset Owner. It's a contact in Salesforce.

This field stores the offboard date for this specific catalog asset, representing when it should be fully removed from active exploitation under the applicable termination or offboarding schedule. It is derived from termination/offboarding processes, not from the original contract term clause.

This lookup links the Schedule Catalog row back to the governing Opportunity (contract). It keeps the asset-level ownership and timing row connected to the same contract spine as the Schedule, supporting end-to-end governance and reporting.

This lookup connects the Schedule Catalog row to its Schedule, indicating which schedule bundle (for example, front catalog, acquisition, termination) this asset-level record belongs to. Together with `Catalog__c`, it completes the junction between contract bundle and individual asset.
This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.

This formula field surfaces the record type or subtype of the parent Schedule (for example, Ownership, Termination Schedule, Distro & Sync – Existing Masters). It allows asset-level records to inherit schedule-level context for routing, validation, and reporting.
This is the date when the client notified us that they'd like to terminate a contract.  It's not available in the contract itself, but in the paperwork for its termination.

A contract can reference different types of catalog. This field is meant to identify if we're talking about a track, album, general asset, sound recording or a compositon (publishing work). It can also be a combination of multiple catalogs with different types in a single contract.
In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the UPC of a track. This field is meant to catch that.

For publishing assets, we usually talk about a Writer and not an artist. In some cases, the contract includes both. The writer name is the legal name of a client mentioned in the schedule part of a contract. Do not include pka.

In some of the new contracts, an option can be tied to a number or tracks, number of albums, and minimum total number of minutes for that deliverable. This is where we're logging the number of albums tied to that option

In some of the new contracts, an option can be tied to a number or tracks, number of albums, and minimum total number of minutes for that deliverable. This is where we're logging the number of tracks tied to that option
This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who created the Add On record. It is audit metadata and is not sourced from contract language.
This picklist stores the currency context for the Add On record in a multi-currency org. It is system metadata used for reporting and does not come directly from contract text.
