For type = Merchandising or Pitching, this field is meant to indicate if the rights are exclusive to us or non-exclusive. The Exclusivity should be listed in the same paragraph as the right itself.

This field records the actual date on which the option or other add-on right was exercised or triggered. It is populated operationally when the company formally exercises the right; it is not usually stated as a fixed date in the original contract.

This field is optional and only applies when type=Option. When a contract includes 1 or multiple options, there's usually a clause that indicates the notice period (usually in days) that the label has to notify the client of their intention to trigger/exercise the option. This field is meant to have that value.
For type = Merchandising or Pitching, this field is meant to indicate if the we are taking a fee off the top. If Fee Type!= No Fee, we will need to extract the split.
For type = Merchandising or Pitching, and Fee Type != No Fee, this field will be required. It indicates the revenue sharing model between us and the client. We save the % paid to the client.
This system field identifies the Salesforce user who last modified the Add On record. It supports auditing and change tracking, not contract extraction.

In some of the new contracts, an option can be tied to a number or tracks, number of albums, and minimum total number of minutes for that deliverable. This is where we're logging the minimum number of minutes.

This master-detail field links the Add On record to its governing Opportunity (contract). Every add-on right must be attached to exactly one Opportunity so that option, merchandising, pitching, and other side-car rights can be reported and governed at the contract level.

This lookup links the Add On record to a specific Financials record when there is a fee, advance, or other monetary commitment tied directly to this add-on right (for example, an option fee or merch guarantee). Use it to connect the right to its corresponding money flow.

This field can be in any type of AddOn. It represents the revenue split between the label and the client for that specific type of addon. It's required for Merchandizing and Pitching. Optional for Options. We save the % paid to the client.

If type = option, this field is required. It defines the genre of the option. Is it an option for additional commitments? (Album or Single) or an option to Buyout the client from their agreement? (Buyout)
When Type = Options, in some contracts, the option extends the contract term by a certain amount of time. This is usually in the paragraph describing the option itself.
This field is required for every single add on. It represents what type of "right" or "option" was added to this contract. Currently, we only support 3, but working on adding others.
This field is required when Type = First Negotiation Rights. It represents the number of days where the client can only negociate with us

This field is required when Type = Matching Rights. It represents the period in days where the Licensee (usually US) agrees to match the Offer the client got from a 3rd party in all material commercial respects.

This field is required when Type = Matching Rights. It refers to the time window in days the Licensor has to consummate the agreement with the third party after the Licensee declines to match the offer

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Depending on who's client in the contract, this is either Artist Name or Company Name.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the primary display name for the account in Salesforce. For individuals or bands, it should match the professional or group name used in the contract header and recitals; for companies, it should match the company name used in the party identification. It acts as the top-level label for the party on which Opportunities, Contacts, and Catalog relationships are built.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field represents the type of client we're signing in a contract. On a high level, it's a company vs an individual. In most contracts, it's going to be Artist, Band, Record Label, or Management Company.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This required picklist classifies the account by its role in our business model (Artist, Band, Brand, Record Label, Publisher, Agency, etc.). It is deduced from how the party is described in the contract (for example 'Artist', 'Label', 'Management Company') and from onboarding context. This classification drives downstream behavior, including which fields are required (for example, `artist_birthday_c` for individuals, `company_name_c` and `type_of_company_c` for companies).

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the date of birth of the individual being signed. It's required for contracts with individuals. Optional for contracts with companies.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the date of birth of the individual artist or band member(s) when the contract is with a natural person. It is needed for age-of-majority checks, minor status, and certain drafting requirements. Populate it from onboarding forms or validated ID documents rather than from the contract PDF wherever possible.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field represents the professional name of the artist or Band. It's required for all contract where we're signing an individual, or contracts signing a company, for 1 or 2 individuals
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the professional or stage name (pka/DBA) under which the artist or band is known in the market and in the contract. It is used heavily in drafting and branding and should match the pka/DBA language in the party identification (for example, 'Jane Doe p/k/a JANE X'). It complements legal name fields such as `dba_name_c`.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field represents the business name of the company we's signing. It's required for all contract where we're signing a business regardless if management or record label.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the full legal business name of the company that is a party to the contract (for example, 'XYZ Records, LLC'). It should match the company name in the contract’s party identification block and is required whenever the counterparty is not a natural person.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field represents the legal name of the artist or the legal name of individuals that form a Band. It's required for all contract where we're signing an individual, or contracts signing a company, for 1 or 2 individuals
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the legal name of the individual artist (or individuals in a band) as used in the contract party block and signature lines. It should not include pka/DBA language. Use it alongside `artist_name_pka_or_dba_c` to clearly distinguish legal identity from professional name in drafting and reporting.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the adress of the entity we're signing. Most contracts will have a version of this, sometimes partial. We'll need to get it, break it into its different field, and complete what's missing.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This composite field represents the full billing address of the legal entity we are signing (individual or company). When extracting from contracts, use the address in the party identification or notices section as the starting point, then normalize it into the component fields (street, city, state, postal code, country). If parts are missing from the contract but provided elsewhere (onboarding forms, email), use those to complete the address for operational use.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This multiselect picklist classifies the musical genre(s) associated with the account (for example, Hip Hop, Pop, EDM). It is curated from A&R, marketing, or external metadata, not contracts, and is used for discovery, routing, and analytics.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the URL to the account’s primary Instagram profile. It helps connect party identity to their social presence for marketing and CMA/CPA purposes and is collected during onboarding or research rather than from contract text.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores a Legal Entity (LE) identifier used by Finance or external systems to uniquely identify the legal entity behind the account. It is part of financial and compliance integration, not a contract extraction.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores a prefilled form link for collecting Letter of Direction (LOD) information associated with the account. It is workflow infrastructure and is not meant to mirror any specific contract clause.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the email address of the primary operational contact for the account (for example, manager, business contact, or label rep). It is used for day-to-day communication and onboarding; formal notice addresses remain modeled on Opportunities and contract-level fields.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the first name of the primary operational contact for the account. It is used for CRM, support, and communications rather than legal identification in contracts.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the last name of the primary operational contact for the account. Together with the other primary contact fields it keeps relationship ownership separate from the legal party name.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the phone number of the primary operational contact for the account. It is used by A&R, Legal, and Ops for quick outreach and is typically gathered via onboarding or CRM updates, not from the contract.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist describes the relationship of the primary contact to the account (for example, Manager, Label Rep, Attorney, Artist). It helps clarify communication lines and is defined operationally rather than through contract language.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the URL or handle link for the account’s Snapchat presence when relevant. It is used mainly for marketing and content programs, not as legal contract data.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the URL to the account’s primary SoundCloud profile. It is collected during onboarding or research to tie social/streaming presence to the account.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the URL to the account’s main Spotify artist or profile page. It is operational metadata for marketing, CPA/CMA, and catalog mapping, not contract-derived.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist tracks the lifecycle status of the account in CMG’s systems (for example, Prospect, Active, Dormant, Offboarded). It is a CRM governance field that summarizes relationship state across deals, not a contract field.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Won't be in the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the URL or handle link to the account’s TikTok profile. It is used by marketing and CPA/CMA teams to connect the client’s audience footprint to contract and catalog data.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field is used for contracts with companies. It defines the type of legal entity behind the company. Or the lack of it. It's sadly not available in all contracts.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist specifies the legal entity form of the company (for example, LLC, Corporation, Partnership, Not Legally Formed). Populate it from the entity suffixes and wording in the contract party block (for example, 'LLC', 'Inc.') or from legal documentation provided during onboarding.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the YouTube link of a client. it's usually in CPA contracts.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the primary YouTube channel URL associated with the account, which is especially important for CPA (Channel Partnership) and CMA deals. It may appear explicitly in CPA contracts or be provided via onboarding; use it as the canonical mapping from the account to the corresponding YouTube channel in platform integrations.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field is required when Type = First Negotiation Rights. It represents the number of days where the client can only negociate with us
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the length of the exclusive negotiation window, in days, during which the client must negotiate only with CMG under a First Negotiation Rights clause. Populate it when `Type__c = First Negotiation Rights` based on the period stated in the clause.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: For type = Merchandising or Pitching, this field is meant to indicate if the rights are exclusive to us or non-exclusive. The Exclusivity should be listed in the same paragraph as the right itself.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist indicates whether the merchandising or pitching right granted under this Add On is exclusive or non‑exclusive in favor of CMG. Populate it when `Type__c` is Merchandising or Pitching by mapping the rights clause to either Exclusive or Non‑Exclusive, as stated or clearly implied in the contract.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: In some of the new contracts, an option can be tied to a number or tracks, number of albums, and minimum total number of minutes for that deliverable. This is where we're logging the number of albums tied to that option
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the number of albums that must be delivered if the option is exercised. Use it only when the option language explicitly quantifies album‑level deliverables (for example, 'one additional studio album') and interpret it together with `Number_of_Masters__c` and `Min_Play_Time_in_minutes__c` for a complete view of the option’s scope.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field is optional and only applies when type=Option. When a contract includes 1 or multiple options, there's usually a clause that indicates the notice period (usually in days) that the label has to notify the client of their intention to trigger/exercise the option. This field is meant to have that value.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist stores the notice period the company must give the client before exercising the option (for example, at least 30 days prior to the end of the term). Map the notice language to one of the governed duration values and use it alongside `Term__c` and the Opportunity‑level term fields when modeling option timing.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: For type = Merchandising or Pitching, and Fee Type != No Fee, this field will be required. It indicates the revenue sharing model between us and the client. We save the % paid to the client.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the client’s share of revenues after any Merchandising or Pitching fee is applied, expressed as a percentage. Populate it when `Type__c` is Merchandising or Pitching and `Fee_Type__c` is not 'No Fee', using the percentage that the client receives under the defined fee structure.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: For type = Merchandising or Pitching, this field is meant to indicate if the we are taking a fee off the top. If Fee Type!= No Fee, we will need to extract the split.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist indicates the structure of any fee CMG takes for Merchandising or Pitching add‑ons before applying revenue splits (for example, no fee, fixed fee, or 'up to' a capped amount). Use it to distinguish between pure participation deals and deals where CMG takes a fee off the top prior to applying client splits.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field is required when Type = Matching Rights. It represents the period in days where the Licensee (usually US) agrees to match the Offer the client got from a 3rd party in all material commercial respects.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field captures the number of days CMG has to decide whether to match a bona fide third‑party offer under a Matching Rights clause. Use it when `Type__c = Matching Rights`, mapping directly from the matching period specified in the agreement.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: In some of the new contracts, an option can be tied to a number or tracks, number of albums, and minimum total number of minutes for that deliverable. This is where we're logging the minimum number of minutes.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field records the minimum total playing time (in minutes) that the option deliverable must achieve (for example, a minimum album length). Use it together with `Number_of_Masters__c` and `Number_of_Albums__c` to capture all quantitative aspects of the option’s deliverables.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This auto‑number field is the system identifier for the Add On record (for example, Add On 1, Add On 2). It does not represent an asset or track title; instead it provides a stable handle for each distinct add‑on right attached to the Opportunity.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: In some of the new contracts, an option can be tied to a number or tracks, number of albums, and minimum total number of minutes for that deliverable. This is where we're logging the number of tracks tied to that option
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the number of individual tracks/masters that are committed under this option or add‑on deliverable. Populate it when the contract states a clear track or master count as part of the option; use it with `Number_of_Albums__c` and `Min_Play_Time_in_minutes__c` to fully describe the deliverable requirement.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field can be in any type of AddOn. It represents the revenue split between the label and the client for that specific type of addon. It's required for Merchandizing and Pitching. Optional for Options. We save the % paid to the client.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the client share percentage of revenues generated from the specific add‑on right represented by this record (for example, merch net receipts, pitching fees, or option exploitation income). Populate it with the client’s percentage, and interpret it alongside `Type__c`, `Fee_Type__c`, and `Fee__c` where applicable.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: If type = option, this field is required. It defines the genre of the option. Is it an option for additional commitments? (Album or Single) or an option to Buyout the client from their agreement? (Buyout)
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist refines option‑type add‑ons by specifying what kind of option is being granted (for example, additional Album, additional Single, Buyout of obligations, Period extension, or Video deliverables). Use it when `Type__c = Option` so downstream logic can distinguish creative-deliverable options from pure buyout or term‑extension options.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: When Type = Options, in some contracts, the option extends the contract term by a certain amount of time. This is usually in the paragraph describing the option itself.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist stores the incremental term that applies if the option is exercised (for example, an additional two years). It should be mapped from the option clause and interpreted together with Opportunity‑level `Initial_Term_Length__c`, `Renewal_Term_Length__c`, and `Recoup_Term__c` to model how the option changes the overall contract duration.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field is required when Type = Matching Rights. It refers to the time window in days the Licensor has to consummate the agreement with the third party after the Licensee declines to match the offer
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the number of days the client (Licensor) has to finalize an agreement with the third party after CMG declines to match the offer under a Matching Rights clause. Populate it when `Type__c = Matching Rights` so downstream processes can track whether the third‑party deal was completed within the allowed window.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field is required for every single add on. It represents what type of \"right\" or \"option\" was added to this contract. Currently, we only support 3, but working on adding others.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist defines the high‑level category of the add‑on right (for example, Option, Merchandising, Pitching, First Negotiation Rights, Matching Rights, Sync, Master‑use). It is the primary way to classify what additional rights beyond the core distribution/licensing/publishing deal are granted under this contract.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Sometimes, the contract defines the album type: EP, Single, Compilation, etc.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist classifies the release type for the catalog item (for example, EP, Single, Compilation, Album) based on how it is described in schedules or release metadata. Use it to normalize album-type language from contracts and metadata into a governed set of values.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: When a track is part of an album, this would be the album name.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the album title associated with the catalog item when the asset forms part of an album or EP. Populate it from schedules, label metadata, or official release information so downstream users can group tracks by album for rights, reporting, and financial analysis.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the artist name(s) on the track or asset. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the primary artist name(s) associated with the catalog item as they appear in contracts, schedules, or official release metadata. It should reflect the credited performing artist for the asset and is required so that catalog can be searched and reported by artist.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the name of the label that the contract is with. It's usually at the top of the contract. Either in the title of the first paragraph. This is not the Artist or a thrid party name. If there is no specified Label, return \"None Specified\"
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This lookup identifies the label/division entity in Salesforce that is contractually responsible for this catalog item. It should align with the label named in the governing contract or associated schedules (if any) and is used to route catalog items to the right division for reporting and governance.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the ISRC of a track. This field is meant to catch that.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the ISRC for the recording represented by this catalog item. Populate it from schedules, label metadata, or distribution systems wherever possible so that recordings can be uniquely identified and matched across platforms and rights systems.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the ISWC of a publishing asset (work). This field is meant to catch that.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the ISWC for the composition (publishing work) represented by this catalog item. Use it to reconcile publishing works with PRO registrations and to tie catalog entries to external rights databases.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This is the canonical catalog item title (for example, track or work name) used throughout Salesforce. It should match the governed title used in schedules and external services so that all downstream objects (Schedule Catalog, Financials, external feeds) can reliably identify the same asset.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: In some cases, the contract includes a schedule with actual release dates for each track or asset. This field is meant to catch that.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the commercial release date for the catalog item (for example, initial public release date) when such a date is known from schedules or metadata. It is used for lifecycle analysis, recency reporting, and alignment with contract-based release commitments.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: When a catalog item mentioned in a contract is a remix of another song, this field is meant to capture the artist name of the remixer. The individual who we're signing to remix a track.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the remixer’s artist name when the catalog item is a remix of another work. It is particularly important for remix distribution or licensing deals where the remixer’s participation and splits are distinct from the original artist’s.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: A contract can reference different types of catalog. This field is meant to identify if we're talking about a track, album, general asset, sound recording or a compositon (publishing work). It can also be a combination of multiple catalogs with different types in a single contract.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist classifies the catalog item as a Track, Album, general Asset, Sound Recording, or Composition (publishing work). It normalizes the way contracts and schedules refer to assets into a governed set of types so that other objects (Schedule, Schedule Catalog, Financials) can interpret what kind of asset they are linked to.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the UPC of a track. This field is meant to catch that.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the UPC associated with the catalog item’s release (for example, album or single UPC). It is used to map catalog items to retail and distribution data and to distinguish between different editions or versions of similar releases.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: For publishing assets, we usually talk about a Writer and not an artist. In some cases, the contract includes both. The writer name is usually the legal name of a client. Mentioned in the schedule part of a contract.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the writer’s legal name for catalog items that represent or include publishing works. Use it when writer information appears in schedules or publishing documentation so catalog can be queried and validated by writer identity alongside artist identity.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the name of the label that the contract is with. It's usually at the top of the contract. Either in the title of the first paragraph. This is not the Artist or a thrid party name. If there is no specified Label, return \"None Specified\"
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This lookup identifies the label/division entity associated with this contact in the context of CMG’s structure (for example, the label they work for or represent). It should mirror the label party identified in the relevant contracts and is used to route label-facing contacts to the correct internal division.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the first name of the contact
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the contact’s legal first name as it should appear in contracts and formal documents. It should match the first name used in the contract party block and signature lines when the contact is a signatory or named individual.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the last name of the contact
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the contact’s legal last name (surname/family name) for use in contracts, signatures, and formal identification. Together with `FirstName`, it must match the way the person is named in the contract when they are a party or signatory.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This would be the full legal name of the contact.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field represents the contact’s full legal name, typically composed from salutation, first, middle, last, and suffix components. It is the canonical legal name for drafting, signatures, and KYC, and should match how the person is named in the contract or associated legal documentation.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This would be the email of the contact. It's usually in the signing block or signing log at the end of the contract
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the primary email address for the contact, used for direct communication and, when applicable, as the email reference in contract signing blocks or routing logs. When extracting from contracts, prefer the email shown in the signature block or designated notices section; otherwise, use onboarding or confirmed operational email addresses.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field indicates the type of the schedule. And as a result, different fields would be required in the schedule catalog object. Which is a joint table between schedule and catalog. This is an enumerated identifier that tags each Schedule with its specific deal subtype (e.g., “Ownership,” “Termination,”). This single value drives all conditional logic: it tells the system which extra fields, page layouts, and validation rules to load in the Schedule–Catalog junction, ensuring that only data relevant to that deal subtype can be displayed, entered, or processed. This field cannot be empty.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: In the Contacts context, this record type identifier classifies the contact into governed subtypes (for example, Client Contact, Legal Contact, A&R Contact) that control which fields, layouts, and business rules apply. The description referencing schedules is generic; here, treat it as the main driver of how the contact is presented and validated in CMG’s CRM.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field represents the amount. It can be the total mentioned in the agreement, or a portion of it if the agreement total is broken into multiple payments.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the monetary value for a single financial commitment row. For simple deals, it may equal the entire amount mentioned in the agreement; for structured deals, it represents only the portion tied to this specific event, tranche, or installment. Use `Type__c`, `SubType__c`, and `CurrencyIsoCode` in combination with this value to express what the amount is for and in which currency.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is a prepaid, typically recoupable payment made to a party (e.g., an artist or producer) against future earnings or royalties.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the total cash advance amount that is contractually committed to the client as an advance against future earnings or royalties. It should align with the aggregate of any installment-level `Amount__c` rows that are specifically labeled as advances, and it is a core input into recoupment modeling alongside `Recoupable__c` and related fields.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field indicates the currency of the selected financial commitment
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist specifies the currency in which the financial amount is denominated (for example, USD, EUR, GBP). It must match the currency referenced in the contract's financial terms and is used by downstream systems for FX conversion, consolidated reporting, and payment processing in multi-currency environments.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is a number field that defines the total number of days CMG has to pay the payment starting the day it’s triggered.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field captures the number of days CMG has to make the payment after the triggering event occurs (for example, "within 30 days of delivery" or "within 15 days after statement"). It is mapped from the payment timing clause and is used with `Event_Completion_Date__c` to derive `Due_Date__c` for each financial row.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is a dropdown field that indicates the trigger for the financial record. It's usually defined right next to the amount
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist classifies the contractual event that causes this financial obligation to become due (for example, Effective date, Execution of contract, Delivery of project, Threshold Pass). It should be chosen based on the language nearest to the amount in the agreement so that each financial row has a clear and auditable trigger.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field indicates HOW the marketing budget can be spent. Does it need client approval? Client can spend it on their own? mutual approval? or label can spend it on their own? It's not required unless the Type and SubType combination = Marketing Budget
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist describes the decision-making model for spending marketing-related funds tied to this financial record (for example, Client Discretion, Label Discretion, Mutual Approval, or No Approval Needed). Use it primarily when `Type__c` and `SubType__c` indicate marketing budgets or advances so that everyone understands who controls marketing spend and under what governance.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field is required when the Type is set to Budget. It allows users to specify whether the budget value represents a minimum or maximum amount.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist refines budget-type financial commitments by indicating whether the amount is a minimum spend requirement (Min Budget) or a maximum authorized cap (Max Budget). Use it only when `Type__c = Budget` so reporting and recoupment logic can distinguish between guaranteed minimum budgets and "up to" caps.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This text field is the display name for the financial record. Instead of a track or asset title, use it to label the financial obligation itself in a human-readable way (for example, "Signing Advance", "Option 1 Marketing Budget", "Tour Support Fee") so users can quickly understand what each row represents without reading all fields.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field is meant for any additional notes around the financial record.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: Use this long-text field to capture concise, operational notes that clarify how this financial row should be interpreted or applied (for example, conditional triggers, carve-outs, or cross-references to specific clauses). Avoid pasting entire clauses; focus instead on brief annotations that help Finance and Legal implement the contract correctly.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field links the financial record to its opportunity (Contract)
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This master-detail field links the financial record to its governing Opportunity (the contract-level spine). Every financial row must be attached to exactly one Opportunity so that advances, budgets, fees, and thresholds can be rolled up and reported at the contract level.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: In some cases, the contract defines who's getting payed for a fee or an advance. In those cases, this field would link to a CONTACT who's the payee defined in the contract. It will need the same fields defined for contacts.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This lookup identifies the specific person or entity (stored as a Contact) who is designated in the contract as the payee for this financial commitment. Use it whenever the agreement clearly names a recipient for the fee or advance so payment routing and reporting can be tied to the correct human or company contact.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field indicates the type of the schedule. And as a result, different fields would be required in the schedule catalog object. Which is a joint table between schedule and catalog. This is an enumerated identifier that tags each Schedule with its specific deal subtype (e.g., “Ownership,” “Termination,”). This single value drives all conditional logic: it tells the system which extra fields, page layouts, and validation rules to load in the Schedule–Catalog junction, ensuring that only data relevant to that deal subtype can be displayed, entered, or processed. This field cannot be empty.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: In the Financials object, this record type identifier classifies the financial record into a governed subtype that can drive page layouts, validation rules, and automation. While the description references schedules generically, here it serves the same purpose: to select which financial configuration and UX apply to this kind of commitment; its value is chosen by system design, not extracted from the contract text.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field captures the recoup percentage needed for a client in order to trigger a payment. It's required when the Type is set to Recoup Threshold.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the minimum recoupment percentage that must be achieved against a defined recoupable base (for example, 100% recouped against advances) before an additional payment is triggered. Use it when `Type__c` indicates a recoup threshold-based payment, and document the recoup base and mechanics in `Notes__c` if they are non-standard.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field indicates if the financial record (budget, advance, fee, etc) is recoupable or not. If the contract mentions that it's recoupable, value is YES. If it mentions that it's not recoupable, value is NO, otherwise, value is N/A
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist classifies whether the amount represented by this financial row is contractually recoupable from the client’s share of revenue or royalties. Set it to "Yes" when the agreement states that the amount is recoupable, "No" when it is expressly non-recoupable, and "N/A" when recoupment concepts do not apply (for example, pure purchase price or final settlement payments).

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original:
This field captures the streaming threshold value required for financial calculations when the Type is set to Streaming Threshold.

In some contracts, a payment is triggered when a client reaches a certain number of streams (this field) in a certain number of days (row 23)
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the required number of streams that must be reached (for example, across a platform or set of platforms) in order for a streaming-based payment to become due. Use it together with `Threshold_of_days__c` to fully capture the performance condition (volume plus time window) specified in the agreement.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field is heavily related to row 24 (Type). It defines on a high level the SUBTYPE of the financial commitment. In combination with row 24, we would know as an example, if it's a marketing advance or marketing budget.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist refines `Type__c` by describing the functional area of the financial commitment (for example, Marketing, Video, Tour, Recording, Signing). The combination of `Type__c` and `SubType__c` should make it clear what the money is for (advance vs budget vs fee, and in which area), which in turn drives approvals, recoupment treatment, and reporting segmentation.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original:
This field specifies the number of days associated with the threshold for payment calculations.

In some contracts, a payment is triggered when a client reaches a certain number of streams (row 21) in a certain number of days (this field)
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the time window, in days, during which a performance threshold (typically the `Streaming_Threshold__c` count) must be met for the payment to be triggered. It turns language like "within 90 days" or "over a 30-day period" into a normalized numeric value.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field is heavily related to row 22 (SubType). It defines on a high level the TYPE of the financial commitment. In combination with row 22, we would know as an example, if it's a marketing advance or marketing budget.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This picklist defines the top-level category of the financial commitment (for example, Advance, Budget, Fee, Purchase Price, Holdback Amount, Ad Credit). It is the primary dimension for grouping and reporting on financial obligations and, together with `SubType__c`, determines which business rules, approval paths, and recoupment logic apply to each row.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This fields indicates the SUB TYPE of row #39. It's dependant on what's entered there.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field indicates the contract subtype and must be interpreted only after Contract_Type__c is known. The subtype refines how rights, term fields, and schedule behavior should be applied for a given contract type (for example, Remixer vs Standard vs Cover Composition, or Synch Representation vs Synch Licensing). Source this from how the deal is framed in the agreement, then map to the governed option set for the relevant Contract_Type__c.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the name of the label that the contract is with. It's usually at the top of the contract. Either in the title of the first paragraph.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the contracting label/division for the opportunity, as named in the contract preamble or party‑identification section. It should represent the company entity (for example, CMG imprint or third‑party label), not the artist or management company. Normalize this value to the governed label/division records used across Accounts, Catalog, and Schedule so cross‑object reporting and routing remain consistent.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field was created for M&A when we initially onboarded them to Sf in 2023. They had this as a column.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the operating budget amount for JV‑style deals when such a budget is defined in the agreement or deal materials. Use it to track the planned spend that may interact with recoupment or profit‑share calculations, and ensure it is interpreted consistently with other JV financial fields.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field was created for M&A when we initially onboarded them to Sf in 2023. They had this as a column.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field describes the base against which JV‑related costs or advances are recouped (for example, label share only, a defined JV profit pool, or specific revenue categories). For JV and M&A‑style deals, use this to document the recoupment base so Finance can configure settlements correctly; treat it as governed recoup logic, not just historical metadata.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is a weird field. It's a number that represents, our of the "Number of New Masters", how many will be distributed as singles?
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field records how many of the committed new masters (MasterNumber__c) are designated as singles under the deal’s release plan. Populate it only when the contract or deal memo explicitly distinguishes a subset of masters that will be treated as singles for release, marketing, or financial purposes.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: use this for when there is a additional album in the option ,EP, etc like for regular distro!
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field captures the period tied to an option commitment (for example, an additional album, EP, or similar deliverable) in distribution or licensing structures. Populate only when an option exists and the contract defines a specific time window for that option (such as how long the label has to exercise it or how long the option term lasts). Keep this aligned with Option_Type__c, Number_of_Options__c, Option_Master_Number__c, and Option_Release_Details__c so option governance stays consistent.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is a merge field with the schedule list (Separate table)
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field is a merge/relationship handle that links the opportunity to its associated Schedule records stored in the separate Schedule object. Do not treat it as a free‑text extraction field. Its purpose is to ensure that deliverables, catalog items, and related schedule terms are correctly joined to the governing opportunity for drafting and downstream exports.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: A selloff period A sell‑off period is a defined period after termination or expiration of a distribution agreement during which the distributor may continue selling existing stock (e.g., manufactured CDs/vinyl). No new units can be manufactured unless expressly permitted. the purpose is to allow an orderly wind‑down and avoid waste or financial loss.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field indicates the length of the sell‑off period after the agreement ends, during which existing physical stock may continue to be sold under the contract. Map the clause language to one of the governed duration options and interpret this in combination with Collection_Period__c and Exploitation_Period__c so all post‑term rights (physical sell‑off vs revenue collection) are modeled consistently.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the period before the end of the term (initial or renewal) usually defined in the terms where the client can give us notice that they're like to terminate. It's basically a minimum notice period for terminating a contract.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field captures the minimum advance‑notice window the client (or company, depending on the clause) must give before the end of the relevant term (initial or renewal) in order to terminate. Map the clause wording to one of the governed duration options and interpret it together with Initial_Term_Length__c, Renewal_Term_Length__c, and Termination_Notice_Date__c so lifecycle events are handled correctly.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field is exclusively used in termination documents. It define if it's we're terminating contracts by Effective Date (1 offboarding date per contract) or by catalog release date (multiple offboard dates per contract). It' tricky to find it in older termination documents. Usually deduced from the termination language.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field classifies how a termination document applies offboarding: either once per contract (effective‑date‑based) or per catalog/asset (initial commercial release‑based). It is sourced from termination paperwork, not the original deal, and drives how offboarding dates are calculated and applied across related Schedule and Schedule Catalog records.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is a dropdown field that explains where the contract is applicable. It's usually referenced as "Territory" or "Territories" in the contract, or implied in a section in the first half. However, it won't be spelled exactly as the options in Salesforce. We'll need some sort of mapping.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field defines the geographic scope of the rights granted under the agreement and must be mapped from the contract’s territory clause (or equivalent grant language) to the governed Salesforce option set. Normalize common wording variants like "worldwide" or "throughout the universe" to World and Universe, and use World Excluding Multiples when the clause lists carve‑outs that should be detailed in Excluded_Territories__c.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the percentage of an asset (or assets) that the label acquired as part of a CoPub or Asset Purchase agreement. It's usually in the first part of a contract in the middle of a paragraph. If this is 0, Keep this field empty.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the percentage of the asset owner’s interest in this specific catalog item that is being acquired under the deal. Use it for line‑item ownership changes in CoPub and asset purchase contexts where the acquisition percentage is defined at the asset level (as opposed to a global acquisition percentage on the Opportunity). If no ownership is acquired for this asset, leave this field blank rather than entering 0%.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: When a track is part of an album, this would be the album name.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This formula field surfaces the album name associated with the linked Catalog item when the asset forms part of an album. It helps users understand album context for each asset in the schedule bundle without navigating back to the Catalog record.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Sometimes, the contract defines the album type: EP, Single, Compilation, etc.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field reflects the governed album type for the asset (for example, EP, Single, Compilation) as defined in the contract schedules or catalog metadata. Use it to distinguish how assets are grouped and marketed at the schedule‑catalog junction level.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the artist name(s) on the track or asset. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This formula field surfaces the artist name(s) for the linked Catalog item so that each Schedule Catalog row carries clear artist context. It is particularly important where a single schedule contains assets from multiple artists or projects.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Writer name
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This lookup identifies the human or entity that owns the relevant interest in this catalog asset for purposes of the ownership percentages tracked on this row (for example, writer or rights holder). It links ownership percentages like `Composition_Ownership__c` and `Master_Ownership__c` to a governed Contact record rather than free text.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: Track name
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This formula field brings in the Catalog item name (typically the track or work title) so each Schedule Catalog record can be read and filtered by asset title without leaving the junction object. It should mirror the `Name` field on the related Catalog record.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the % of a composition owned by the human involved in the track/catalog. The human is represented as Asset Owner. It's a contact in Salesforce.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the percentage of the composition (publishing work) owned by the contact referenced in `Asset_Owner__c` for this specific Schedule Catalog line. It is used to express writer‑side or publisher‑side ownership at the asset level and should align with the ownership splits in the contract’s publishing schedules.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the ISRC of a track. This field is meant to catch that.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This formula field surfaces the ISRC of the linked Catalog item, when available, so that asset‑level rights and ownership rows can be matched precisely to distribution metadata. It is especially useful for resolving duplicates and confirming that the correct recording is being governed by this Schedule Catalog row.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the ISWC of a publishing asset (work). This field is meant to catch that.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This formula field surfaces the ISWC of the linked publishing work so Schedule Catalog rows can be reconciled to external PRO and publishing registrations. It supports precise ownership and rights management for compositions included on the schedule.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the % of a sound recording (or Track) owned by the human involved in the track/catalog. The human is represented as Asset Owner. It's a contact in Salesforce.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the percentage of the master (sound recording) owned by the contact in `Asset_Owner__c` for this particular asset. Use it to represent per‑asset master ownership splits at the junction level, in alignment with the master ownership details found in schedules or acquisition schedules.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This auto‑number field is the system identifier for the Schedule Catalog row. It provides a stable reference for the ownership/rights line item itself rather than representing contract text; the actual track/work name should be surfaced from `Catalog_Name__c`.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the date when the client notified us that they'd like to terminate a contract. It's not available in the contract itself, but in the paperwork for its termination.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field captures the date on which termination notice was given as it applies to this specific asset in a termination or uncrossing schedule. Use it when termination paperwork specifies asset‑level or catalog‑level notice timing that must be tracked separately from the Opportunity‑level termination notice date.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: A contract can reference different types of catalog. This field is meant to identify if we're talking about a track, album, general asset, sound recording or a compositon (publishing work). It can also be a combination of multiple catalogs with different types in a single contract.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This formula field reflects the catalog type (Track, Album, Asset, Sound Recording, Composition) for the linked Catalog item. It allows Schedule Catalog to be filtered and governed by asset type while inheriting that classification from the master Catalog record.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the UPC of a track. This field is meant to catch that.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This formula field surfaces the UPC associated with the linked Catalog item so asset‑level rights rows can be reconciled with retail and distribution systems. It is particularly helpful when multiple versions or editions of a release share similar titles but have distinct UPCs.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: For publishing assets, we usually talk about a Writer and not an artist. In some cases, the contract includes both. The writer name is the legal name of a client mentioned in the schedule part of a contract. Do not include pka.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This formula field surfaces the writer’s legal name associated with the linked Catalog composition. It is used for quick reference at the Schedule Catalog level, ensuring that per‑asset publishing splits can be read alongside the corresponding writer identity without navigating back to Catalog or Contacts.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: When a track is part of an album, this would be the album name.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores the album name associated with the catalog items grouped under this Schedule when those items form part of a defined album in the contract materials or schedules. Use it when the schedule is clearly album-based so downstream users can quickly understand which album this schedule bundle refers to.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This auto-number field is the system-generated identifier for the Schedule (for example, Schedule 1, Schedule 2). It does not carry semantic contract data itself; it simply provides a stable handle used in the UI and in relationships to Schedule Catalog records and the governing Opportunity.

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: This field indicates the type of the schedule. And as a result, different fields would be required in the schedule catalog object. Which is a joint table between schedule and catalog.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This record type identifier classifies the Schedule into a governed schedule subtype (for example, Front Catalog + Remixes, Ownership, Termination Schedule). Its value determines which fields, layouts, and validation rules apply both on the Schedule itself and on related Schedule Catalog records. It is not extracted from the contract as text; instead, it is chosen based on how the contract frames the schedule’s role (existing masters vs acquisition vs termination vs uncrossing, etc.).

definition_expansion_suggestions.definition_original: In some cases, the contract includes a schedule with actual release dates for each track or asset. This field is meant to catch that.
definition_expansion_suggestions.expanded_definition_suggestion: This field stores a schedule-level release date when the contract or attached schedules identify a common release date for the assets in this Schedule (for example, a compilation or group release date). Use it when a single date applies across the bundle; otherwise, use Catalog- or Schedule Catalog–level release dates for asset-specific timing.

alias_rules.source_evidence: Contract_Subtype__c.options include 'Synch Representation' and 'Synch Licensing' while governed fields and other options use the 'Sync' prefix for synchronization rights.
Multiple opportunity field definitions describe 'synchronization licensing rights' while field keys and options normalize the concept under the 'Sync' prefix.
Contract_Type__c.options contains 'Co-Pub' while text in definitions references 'CoPub' and 'Co-Publishing' as equivalent concepts.
Publishing_Rights__c.options contains 'CoPub' but narrative definitions refer to 'CoPub' and 'Co-Publishing' interchangeably when describing publishing rights structures.
Contract_Type__c.options use the short label 'Pub Admin' even though the underlying deal type is described in long form as 'Publishing Administration' in several definitions.
Option sets for rights‑related fields use the hyphenated form 'Non-Exclusive' while contract clauses commonly spell it 'non exclusive' without a hyphen.
Contract_Type__c.options currently include a misspelled value 'Assignement' that must still be matched from standard legal usage of the word 'assignment'.
Territories__c.options contain 'World and Universe', a canonical representation for grants phrased as 'worldwide' or 'throughout the universe' in contract territory clauses.
RecordTypeId.options include 'Schedule 1 - Catalog Acquisition - Masters'; contracts frequently refer to this in shorthand as 'Schedule 1'.
RecordTypeId.options include 'Schedule 2 - Catalog Acquisition - Compositions'; contracts and riders typically shorten this to 'Schedule 2'.
RecordTypeId.options include 'Distro & Sync - Existing Masters'; opportunity-level definitions refer to 'existing masters' and 'back catalog' using this phrasing.
Back catalog concepts at the Opportunity level are often described as 'existing masters' or 'back catalog'; the governed schedule type capturing that role is 'Distro & Sync - Existing Masters'.
Schedule Catalog definitions describe `Catalog_Name__c` as 'Track name' and `Name` as 'Schedule Catalog Name'; contracts commonly refer to the governed asset as 'track name'.
Schedule Catalog and Opportunity definitions describe composition splits as a percentage owned by a writer; contracts often refer to this as 'writer share' in the schedules.
Schedule Catalog uses `Master_Ownership__c` to represent the percentage of a sound recording owned by an asset owner; deal language frequently calls this the 'master share'.
Termination and uncrossing processes refer to asset removal timing as 'offboarding'; the governed field name on Schedule Catalog is `Offboard_Date__c`.
Both Opportunity and Schedule Catalog objects use '*Termination Notice Date*' fields for the date notice is given, while termination paperwork may simply say 'on receipt of termination notice'.

Catalog definitions describe Name and Type__c primarily in terms of 'track name or asset name'; contracts and schedules often use 'track' as the shorthand for catalog items that must be modeled more generally in Salesforce.
Contracts and schedules frequently refer to individual recordings as 'songs'; the governed Catalog Type__c uses 'Track' to represent this same concept.
Account and Catalog governance text references professional names as 'pka'; Catalog uses 'Artist Name' as the canonical representation of the performing identity.
Contract schedules and recital sections often call out the 'performing artist'; Catalog stores this in the governed 'Artist Name' field.
Catalog and Schedule Catalog definitions describe writer-side identity using 'Writer Name'; contracts commonly refer simply to 'writer' or 'songwriter' in publishing schedules.

Division2__c is defined as 'the name of the label that the contract is with'; internal label routing also uses the 'Label' picklist. Contract language usually uses 'label' or 'record label' generically.
Metadata and ingestion pipelines often treat UPC as the primary 'release ID' for album/single products while Catalog stores this identifier under the governed UPC__c field.
Glossary describes this object as 'Add Ons' and field labels use 'Add On'; deal emails and notes frequently shorten this to 'addon' or 'add-on'.
The governed sheet is 'Add Ons'; natural language references often use the hyphenated form 'add-on' to describe the same concept.
Type__c.options include 'First Negotiation Rights'; contracts and term sheets often refer to the same right as 'first negotiation' without the word 'rights'.
Type__c.options include 'Matching Rights'; clauses may describe this as a 'matching right' or 'right to match' rather than using the exact picklist label.
Field definitions and options reference 'Merchandising' as an Add On type; internal and contract language often uses 'merch' as shorthand for the same rights.
Add On and Opportunity term fields distinguish between core term and option‑exercise windows; contracts may conflate 'option period' with the notice window used for Exercise_Notice__c.
Account field `artist_name_pka_or_dba_c` is described as the professional name (pka or dba); contracts and onboarding often use 'p/k/a' when referring to stage names.
The glossary refers to this field as 'Artist Name (pka or dba)'; contracts and forms may reference 'doing business as (dba)' for professional names.
Accounts uses `dba_name_c` with label 'Legal Name'; contract party blocks and signature lines refer to 'legal name' for individuals.
The glossary describes `Account_Name_c` as the display name for the client; internal users refer generically to 'the account' as the same concept.
Account_Type_c.options include 'Record Label'; contract recitals frequently describe parties as 'record label' or 'label' rather than using structured picklist values.
Account_Type_c description references management companies; contracts and emails often abbreviate to 'mgmt company'.
Account-level fields include 'YouTube', 'YouTube 2', 'YouTube 3', and 'YouTube Channel Name'; CPA contracts refer to 'YouTube channel' in narrative clauses.
Contacts and Opportunities both reference 'Contact Email' fields; the core Contacts object uses the `Email` field as the primary email store.
The Contacts glossary calls Name 'Legal Name' and FirstName/LastName 'Legal First Name' and 'Legal Last Name'; contracts frequently refer to 'legal name' for signatories.
The Contacts glossary labels `Phone` as 'Business Phone'; users and contracts often just refer to 'phone' or 'business phone' interchangeably.
The glossary labels `Fax` as 'Business Fax'; contracts sometimes reference 'fax' for notice information without the 'business' qualifier.

The Contacts sheet includes a `Role__c` multiselect alongside `Title` and `Department`; contracts and internal docs typically describe a person’s 'role' with a mix of title, department, and functional labels.

Financial deal language frequently abbreviates 'Minimum Guarantee' as 'MG' while the underlying economics are modeled using Amount__c with appropriate Type/SubType classifications and explanatory notes.
Contracts often refer to a 'min guarantee' amount, which is captured as an Amount__c row and may be described further in Notes__c.
The governed financial Type__c uses 'Advance' while agreements often phrase it as an 'advance payment' or 'payment of an advance'.
SubType__c includes 'Signing' to represent signing-related consideration; contracts commonly call this a 'signing bonus' or 'sign-on bonus'.
SubType__c contains 'Marketing' and Marketing_Advance_Mutually_Approved__c describes how marketing budgets may be spent; internal and contract language often uses 'marketing spend' for these amounts.
Min_Max__c has an option 'Max Budget' to indicate a capped budget; contracts often describe this as a 'budget cap' or maximum spend.
Min_Max__c has an option 'Min Budget' to represent a minimum committed spend; negotiators sometimes refer to this concept as a 'floor' or 'budget floor'.
Recoupment clauses frequently frame recoveries as 'recoupable from net receipts' even when they do not use the explicit adjective 'recoupable' that the Recoupable__c field captures.

Opportunities.section_focus: Opportunities is the contract spine: it encodes who the deal is with, what type of agreement it is, what rights and economic structures it governs, over what term and territories, and with which high-level options, restrictions, and approval mechanics.

section_headers.section_description: High-level contract type, subtype, division/label, and related deal-identity fields that classify what kind of agreement this is.
Fields that define when the deal starts, how long it lasts, how and when it renews, and how termination and sell-off/collection windows are structured.
Territorial coverage and related scope-of-rights fields that define where and to what assets or rights the deal applies.
Top-level financial and economic governance: advances, fees, revenue splits for different income types, thresholds, distribution fees, and profit-sharing constructs.
Fields describing non-core but material rights (options, sync, merch, neighboring rights, pitching, CPA/CMA types) and how they attach to the base deal.
Publishing-specific constructs: admin vs copub, PRO affiliation, retention/collection for publishing, writer splits, and whether publishing components are present.
Higher-order governance around what CMG can do (sample/sync restrictions, sync approvals, restricted CMA content, approval and matching rights, what’s uncrossed).
Contractual deliverable counts and obligations: numbers of masters, singles, options, social posts, and how schedules/cross-collateralization behave.
Channel Partnership and Content Monetization specific term lengths, renewals, terminations, splits, and content scope.
Formal legal aspects like notary details, inducement pages, offboarding/termination paperwork targeting, and what exactly is amended or terminated.
Internal-only status, drafting, approval, and helper fields that drive workflows but are not directly clause-extracted.

Financials.section_focus: Financials is the governed ledger of individual monetary commitments under a contract, turning each obligation into a structured row with amounts, types, triggers, timing, recoupment, and payee context that downstream finance can execute against.

section_headers.section_description: Base amount, currency, and type/subtype fields that classify what each financial row represents economically.
Fields that define what event triggers the obligation, when it is due, when it is paid, and its current status.
Fields that capture recoupability, recoup thresholds, streaming thresholds, and related performance windows.
Linkage back to the governing Opportunity (contract) and the designated payee contact so money can be routed correctly.
Notes, record type choice, and other fields that shape how the financial row behaves in layouts, rules, and reporting.
Purely system-generated or operational metadata used for auditing and multi-currency support.

Schedule.section_focus: The Schedule section defines the contract-level bundles of assets that sit between the Opportunity and individual Catalog items. Each Schedule represents a governed “bucket” of works (front catalog, back catalog, acquisition, termination, ownership, etc.) that shares a common role in the deal. Schedules answer: “Which group of assets is in play under this contract, under what schedule type, and how should downstream systems treat that bundle?” They do not carry per-asset splits—that lives in Schedule Catalog and Catalog—but they are critical for correctly routing, typing, and governing all attached assets.

section_headers.section_description: Groups fields that link a Schedule to its governing Opportunity and other high‑level entities, making this record the structural bridge between the contract and its attached catalog.

Groups fields that classify what kind of Schedule this is (e.g., front catalog, catalog acquisition, termination, ownership, uncrossing). These choices drive which downstream fields, layouts, and rules apply in Schedule and Schedule Catalog.

Groups fields that describe the bundle of assets on the Schedule (e.g., album name, high‑level work description, catalog grouping) so users can quickly understand what content is being governed without looking at every individual asset row.

Groups fields that capture schedule-level dates and timing (e.g., release dates that apply to the bundle, acquisition or offboarding timing if expressed at the schedule level), supporting lifecycle and offboarding logic across all attached assets.

Groups fields that describe how ownership or economic interest is changing at the schedule level (e.g., percentage of seller’s interest acquired by purchaser), especially for acquisition, ownership, or termination schedules.

section_headers.section_title: Schedule – System Metadata, Counts & Audit Trail
section_headers.section_description: Groups fields that are system/operational (auto-numbered name, created/modified by, currency context, count of attached Schedule Catalog items). These fields support reporting, auditing, and performance tracking but are not extracted from clauses themselves. Schedule Catalog

Schedule Catalog.section_focus: The Schedule Catalog section is the asset‑level truth table for your contracts. It’s where each individual catalog item (track, master, composition) is joined to a specific contract and schedule, with its own ownership, splits, and lifecycle dates. If Opportunities are the contract spine and Schedules are the bundles, Schedule Catalog is the row‑by‑row ledger of “who owns what, for which asset, under which deal, and until when.”

section_headers.section_title: Schedule Catalog – Contract ↔ Schedule ↔ Asset Junction
section_headers.section_description: Fields that link each row to its governing Opportunity, its Schedule, and its Catalog item, making this the central join point for legal, structural, and asset metadata.

section_headers.section_title: Schedule Catalog – Asset Identity & Metadata Surface
section_headers.section_description: Fields that surface key catalog attributes (track/work title, artist, writer, album, ISRC, ISWC, UPC, asset type) so you can identify the exact asset a rights/ownership line applies to without leaving the junction.

Fields that capture master and composition ownership percentages, acquired percentages, and the Asset Owner contact for each line, modeling granular splits exactly as defined in schedules and acquisition language.

Fields that track asset‑level actual termination dates, termination notice dates, and offboard dates, turning schedule‑ and contract‑level termination constructs into concrete lifecycle events for each catalog item.

section_headers.section_title: Schedule Catalog – Schedule Context & Inherited Typing
section_headers.section_description: Fields that inherit or reflect schedule‑level context (e.g., schedule record type, schedule role) so

section_headers.section_title: each asset line “knows” whether it belongs to an ownership, termination, distro & sync – existing
section_headers.section_description: masters, or other schedule type.

Fields that hold system metadata (created/modified by, currency context, auto‑number) and links to instructions like Letters of Direction (LOD), supporting auditability, payment routing, and operational governance without adding new legal semantics. Catalog

Catalog.section_focus: The Catalog section is your canonical asset registry. It defines each work or recording as a single source of truth—what it is (track, album, composition), who is associated with it (artist, writer, label), and how it connects to external IDs and services (ISRC, ISWC, UPC, Spotify, Apple). Contracts, Schedules, and Schedule Catalog all point into Catalog so that rights, ownership, and financials are always attached to the same governed asset record, not scattered across free text.
