section_headers.section_description: Fields that define the core identity of the catalog item: title, artist name, writer name, asset type (track/album/composition), and album context. These establish “what this thing is” in a way all other objects can reference.

section_headers.section_title: Catalog – Rights Streams & Business Side (Master vs Publishing)
section_headers.section_description: Fields that classify which right-streams are in scope for the asset (master, publishing, or both), and which internal label/division is responsible. These support downstream rights, routing, and deal-mapping decisions.

Fields that store ISRC, ISWC, UPC, external asset IDs, and platform URLs (Spotify, Apple Music, etc.). They make Catalog the join point between your internal records and DSPs, PROs, legacy systems, and ingestion pipelines.

Fields that connect catalog items back to governing Opportunities or specific instructions (like LODs). These links allow you to answer “under what deal and instructions is this asset currently governed?” from the asset side.

Fields that track internal ownership of the catalog record itself (record owner, A&R assignment, label routing), supporting workflow, responsibility, and internal governance that is not pulled from the contract.
Fields that are purely system metadata (created by, last modified by, 18‑char ID, currency context) ensuring catalog records can be audited, integrated, and debugged without ambiguity. Add ons

Add Ons.section_focus: The Add Ons (V2 Add Ons) section captures all rights and options that sit on top of the core deal—things like merchandising, pitching, additional album/track options, first negotiation, and matching rights. It turns these side-car rights into structured, queryable records so you can see, for each contract, exactly what extra rights exist, how long they last, how they are exercised, and what economic terms (splits/fees) attach to them.

section_headers.section_title: Add Ons – Core Right Type & Classification
section_headers.section_description: Fields that define what kind of add-on we’re talking about (Option, Merchandising, Pitching, First Negotiation, Matching Rights, etc.) and the subtype of option when applicable (album, single, buyout, extension).
Fields that quantify what’s on the table when an option or add-on is exercised: number of albums, number of masters, minimum play time in minutes, and any other measurable deliverable commitments.

section_headers.section_title: Add Ons – Timing, Term & Exercise Mechanics
section_headers.section_description: Fields that describe how long the add-on right lives and how it’s exercised: exercise dates, exercise notice periods, exclusive negotiation periods, matching periods, and any term extensions tied to options.

Fields that capture the economic model for the add-on: whether there is a fee off the top, what that fee structure is, and what percentage of revenues the client receives (splits) for the specific add-on right.

section_headers.section_title: Add Ons – Contract Spine & Financial Linkage
section_headers.section_description: Fields that tie each add-on right back to its governing Opportunity and, when applicable, to specific Financials rows (e.g., option fees, merch guarantees), ensuring these side-car rights are anchored to the main contract and its money flows.

section_headers.section_title: Add Ons – System Identity & Operational Tracking
section_headers.section_description: Fields that provide system identity and tracking for each add-on record (auto-number name, exercise date as actually logged, etc.), enabling teams to manage, audit, and report on the lifecycle and utilization of each add-on right. Accounts

Accounts.section_focus: The Accounts section is your party identity spine. It defines who the client is at a legal and operational level (individual vs company, artist vs label vs management), where they live and do business, and how CMG interacts with them (contact points, payment preferences, social links, onboarding status). Contracts, Opportunities, Contacts, and Catalog all hang off these governed Account records so analysts never have to guess “who is this deal actually with?” or “which legal entity owns this relationship?”.

section_headers.section_description: Fields that define who the account is in legal and professional terms: ○ Legal vs professional/brand names (legal name, DBA/pka, company name, account name). ○ Account type (artist, band, record label, management company, etc.). These anchor contracts and deals to a single, governed identity.

Fields that describe what kind of entity you’re dealing with: ○ Type of Company (LLC, corporation, partnership, not legally formed). ○ State of formation, inside vs outside USA. This is critical for legal drafting, tax handling, and compliance.

Fields that capture billing, shipping, and contact addresses (street, city, state, postal code, country, geocodes). These support: ○ Where notices and payments are sent. ○ Jurisdictional analysis across contracts (e.g., which state law or territory might matter).

Fields that hold primary communication vectors for the account: ○ Phone, fax, primary contact info (email, name, relationship, phone). ○ Website and social links (YouTube, Spotify, TikTok, Instagram, etc.). These are not usually in contracts but are essential for ongoing relationship management and CPA/CMA operations.

section_headers.section_title: Accounts – Deal History, Financial Signals & A&R Context
section_headers.section_description: Fields that summarize how this party behaves across deals: ○ Roll-ups and metrics (total # of deals, term deals, won deals, CMG profit). ○ Current earnings, current advance total, payment frequency/interval/threshold. ○ A&R assignment, status, tiering/Einstein tier. These help analysts and A&R see the commercial footprint of an account.

Fields that wire the account into onboarding and external systems: ○ Typeform IDs, prefill links (account, LOD, deal term). ○ Data.com/Jigsaw IDs, legacy division, LE ID, external IDs. This lets operations and tooling use the Account as the stable join point across apps.

Fields that are especially relevant for CMA/CPA and monetization: ○ CMA restricted content notes. ○ YouTube channel links and names. ○ Social/streaming links used in channel partnership deals. These fields bridge party identity with where their content actually lives.

Fields that support internal governance and automation: ○ Owner, created/modified fields, rollups, “onboarded” flag. ○ Derived/formula flags (individual vs company, representing artists vs not). These are not contract-extracted; they keep Account data operationally healthy and auditable. Contacts

Contacts.section_focus: The Contacts section defines the **people-level spine** that sits under Accounts and Opportunities. It answers: “Who are the humans involved in this relationship, what roles do they play (artist, manager, lawyer, A&R rep, signatory), and how do we reach them?” Contacts are not usually legal counterparties themselves, but they are the signers, approvers, and day‑to‑day operators who make contracts real. This section normalizes identity, roles, and communication details so contract notices, signatures, and workflows consistently hit the right person. urces:

section_headers.section_description: Fields that define *who this person is* for legal and drafting purposes: FirstName`, `LastName`, `MiddleName`, `Suffix`, `Name`, `Birthdate`, `Salutation`. These support correct naming in contracts, signatures, and KYC/age checks.

section_headers.section_title: Contacts – Relationship to Account & Role in Our World
section_headers.section_description: Fields that connect the person to the party and explain what they do: AccountId`, `Role__c`, `Title`, `Department`, `Division2__c`, `Purpose__c`, `ReportsToId`. These tell you whether someone is an artist, manager, lawyer, label rep, or internal liaison and how they map into the org tree.

Fields that store how we reach the contact and what’s allowed: Email`, `Secondary_Email__c`, `Phone`, `MobilePhone`, `HomePhone`, `OtherPhone`, AssistantPhone`, plus `HasOptedOutOfEmail`, `DoNotCall`, `HasOptedOutOfFax`. These drive operational communication and ensure we respect opt‑outs and compliance flags.

Fields that capture where the contact is located: MailingAddress` + components, `OtherAddress` + components, and the normalized Contact_*__c` address fields. These are used for correspondence, jurisdictional context, and document generation (notice blocks, signature pages).

Fields that support CRM health and external systems: Created/Last Modified fields, `OwnerId`, `Id`/`Contact_Id__c`/`ContactIdNumber__c`, Jigsaw/Data.com IDs, Typeform mapping fields, `TODAY__c`. These are not contract fields; they enable automation, integration, and auditability around the human records tied to deals. If you want to iterate next, we can now: Review any section you’re unsure about for thin spots or inconsistencies, or Start a **Pass 2** on a specific sheet (e.g., Opportunities or Financials) focusing purely on better expansion suggestions or more alias rules.
